SPEECH.SPEAKER: Troeth Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I was contending that being of mature age and being long-term unemployed are two great barriers to re-entry into the work force. As one witness told the Senate Employment, Education and Training Committee:

SPEECH.PARA: We need to get to people before they become de-motivated and totally debilitated. That is essential. It is no good waiting until someone has been unemployed for two years before you come along and offer some assistance.
There is clearly a need to make the whole system more flexible. National programs must be tailored to the needs of individual regions in order for them to have any chance of being effective.

PARA.TAB: During the hearings for the unemployment report there were cases presented of programs successfully running at a community level that were to have their funding stopped because they did not fit neatly into department categories. The government prefers to see people taken off the long-term unemployment lists and placed in subsidised job projects. This serves the purpose of making the unemployment figures appear rosier but unfortunately does little for the unemployed worker in the long term.

One of the programs specifically targeted to indigenous people is the community development employment project scheme, CDEP. The evidence put to the Senate long-term unemployment inquiry suggested that opinion in the Aboriginal community is far from supportive of the scheme. Said one indigenous witness of CDEP:

SPEECH.PARA: It is also a way of disguising unemployment figures in terms of Aboriginal people.
The witness also contended that CDEP failed to provide adequate training for future employment.

PARA.TAB: The following estimates of various employment programs show the incidence of unemployment around three months after programs assistance had ended. For instance, in Aboriginal employment schemes, 57.3 per cent were still unemployed; in the program known as jobtrain, 63.4 per cent; in jobclubs, 59.4 per cent; in jobskills, 60.3 per cent; and in LEAP, 60.7 per cent. Even the most successful of the government's employment programs had an unemployment rate of 37.6 per cent three months after completion.

If we look at the numbers in continuing program assistance, that is, people in another training program three months after finishing one, the figures are even more damning. They are 48.2 per cent in OLMA; 31 per cent in jobtrain; 27.4 per cent in Aboriginal employment; 29.8 per cent in jobclubs; and 19.1 per cent in LEAP. A more cynical person than I would suggest that this plethora of training programs was being used to remove people from unemployment lists in the lead-up to the election. Unfortunately, even these are not entirely successful, as the unemployment figure has increased over the past few months from a general level of 8.2 per cent in June to 8.7 last month.

This government has nothing to be proud of as regards Australia's unemployment problem. The government has even stopped producing youth unemployment figures because it claims they are too volatile. What are they trying to hide? We know what they are trying to hide: very high youth unemployment figures in many urban and many rural and regional centres throughout Australia. This government likes to talk about the $2.2 billion it has spent on Working Nation but, when all the rhetoric is laid aside, the government cannot escape the fact that there are still 787,600 people classified as unemployed by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, and one-third of that total are classified as long-term unemployed. This government has failed to adequately address the massive unemployment problem still faced by this country.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with considerable pleasure that I rise today to speak on the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill 1995. I will only be talking about schedule 1, but I do want to go into some of the historic background of how we are where we are today on this particular issue.

PARA.TAB: It is a very important day for many pensioners because it is the end, once this legislation becomes effective next year, of unrealised capital growth treated as income for pension purposes. When the whole concept of unrealised capital gains came before us in 1992, only the Democrats said that it was unworkable, that it was unfair, and we pointed out a whole range of other problems, including the fact that you are actually dissuading people from investing in Australian companies. Having listened to Senator Troeth's speech and the notes that she has made regarding unemployment, one would have thought that the government would actually be encouraging people to invest in Australian companies, but not so.

We continued the pressure on the government to change its mind and to remove those provisions. It was not until the community began to feel the effects of this treatment of shares, and particularly the effect on their pensions, that momentum built up and eventually, towards the end of 1993, the government agreed to some changes. It agreed to take out retrospectivity so that pensioners and part pensioners who had bought shares prior to August 1992 were no longer subjected to unrealised capital growth test, and this helped more than 100,000 retired Australians.

But we did not stop there. What we wanted to see, and what we are finally seeing, is that measure removed altogether. The inequity and the incredible bureaucratic problems with this, the continuing assessment of what the share gains were month after month, highlighted for many pensioners real difficulties in the possibility of them maintaining their investment in shares. Unfortunately, we will see that many have decided that it simply is not worth the hassle any longer and have decided to sell their shares and move their investments elsewhere.

But we continued to press for a review of the income and assets test for age pensions and, eventually when the government agreed to this, we were very pleased to see that it was conducted by Ageing Agendas in a fashion that enabled huge numbers of people to have their voices heard, to put in submissions. It was the findings of that review plus, I suspect, the growing opposition from pensioner groups across Australia that has seen the last of unrealised capital growth. We already heard in this year's May budget that the minister would be introducing extended deeming rates on all financial investments from 1 July next year.

The extended deeming will apply to pensioners' financial investments, including bank accounts, term deposits, shares, friendly society bonds and other managed investments such as equity trusts. It effectively means that capital growth or unrealised capital gains on shares and managed investments will not be treated as income. Therefore, for this reason and for its simplicity, the Democrats are supporting this extended deeming. We see it as a fairer, more equitable assessment method of financial investments for those who wish to qualify to receive an age pension.

Extended deeming has also won, after considerable debate and discussion, the support from pensioner and welfare groups, such as the Council on the Ageing, Australian Pensioners and Superannuants Federation and the Australian Council of Social Service. What opposition there has been to this legislation has come mainly from the Australian Friendly Societies Association, whose members feel they will be disadvantaged because the two-tiered deeming rates do not recognise those investments, like friendly society saved bonds that pre-pay tax.

The Democrats have been concerned and still are concerned about those pensioners and part-pensioners with friendly society bonds. It is obvious that, on present rates of return, these investments—because, as I said, they pre-pay tax at 33 per cent—cannot return their investors anywhere near the proposed extended deeming rates of five per cent and seven per cent. As a result, the Australian Friendly Societies Association, on behalf of its members, has sought an amendment which would introduce a modified deeming rate for pre-taxed investments. The proposal is for a modified rate that is less than the 33 per cent for pre-paid tax investments.

The problem that the Democrats have with such an amendment is that it fundamentally changes the idea behind extended deeming. It ceases to offer equity. Instead it introduces a product based deeming rate. This could lead to demands that other investment products receive the same treatment. It jeopardises one of the main advantages of extended deeming: its simplicity and emphasis on higher yielding investments. It is encouragement for pensioners to actually go out and do the best possible thing they can with their money than to simply have a flat deeming rate, whatever it is they are able to earn.

I am also concerned that any broader amendment to protect friendly society bonds could attract pensioners to an investment which, for the vast majority of them, is not an attractive proposition. As pointed out by the Australian Pensioners Superannuants Federation, two-thirds of pensioners do not pay tax, so paying 33 per cent on friendly society bonds makes them a very unattractive investment in the first place. Even a recent survey by the Australian Friendly Societies Association found that almost 42 per cent of its members paid no tax and 29 per cent are in the marginal 20 per cent tax group.

To agree to a special product based deeming rate for friendly society bonds would encourage, I think, pensioners to maintain these investments and not to move on to take full advantage of the benefits of extended deeming. That does not mean we should not be concerned for those pensioners left holding friendly society bonds and, in particular, those with the smaller friendly societies.

We understand that larger friendly societies have the scope to offer their members a range of other products that could mean returns either matching, if not bettering, the proposed deeming rates. It is the smaller societies, most of them based in Victoria, who are very much limited as to the products they can offer their members. We must also remember that many pensioners and part-pensioners do not want to be forced by this government to re-invest their savings. They have chosen their retirement investment portfolio for its security. They do not want to be forced to change now. It is these pensioners' concerns the Australian Democrats are most concerned about. We really do need to address them.

Friendly societies naturally are concerned about a run on investment once deeming is introduced. That is a real concern. Most friendly societies have been assuring members they can meet any call on funds by their investors. Indeed if there was such a run, particularly a run on the smaller friendly societies, from pensioners wishing to sell their investments, then this legislation does have a provision that can be used to exclude certain investments from extended deeming and so protect the investors.

Section 1084 of the legislation provides for the minister to make a determination to exclude specified financial investments or a specified class of financial investment from the deeming provisions. This would have the effect that only the actual return on the specified investments, if any, would be taken into account under the incomes test. I have sought and got assurances in writing from the minister that this provision would be used to protect any friendly societies finding themselves in such difficulties.

It seems obvious to me that this anomaly that finds friendly societies saved bonds disadvantaged by extended deeming would be better addressed in the tax system rather than in social security. Treasury is currently conducting a review of the whole trustee tax issue. Part of that review would be to provide friendly societies with the opportunity of offering bonus paying bonds which are untaxed at source and assessed in the hands of the individual investor.

The Australian Friendly Societies Association has requested that Treasury, as a matter of urgency, give a firm commitment that such a change would be forthcoming to avoid the problem of those pensioners and part-pensioners with friendly society investments being forced to sell their investments before or soon after the introduction of extended deeming next year. Solving this problem through the tax legislation is, it seems to me, the more complete and permanent solution. I urge the government to allow friendly societies to be able to offer bonus paying bonds untaxed at source for the sake of those pensioners and part-pensioners who do not want to be forced to sell up their friendly society investments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am in a quandary because I have to speak to three bills. I will speak to two of them and my colleague Senator Margetts will speak to the third. I was also in a quandary over which one to speak to first. It is almost arbitrary, but I will speak to the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill first because it has only one amendment whereas the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Carer Pension and Other Measures) Bill has several amendments. If I run out of time I can speak about that during the committee stage.

PARA.TAB: The Senate is debating the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill 1995 which puts into place a number of changes to the two principal acts of the title. The major changes enacted by the bill are welcomed and have the support of the Greens (WA). That said, there are some measures in the bill which we are concerned about as seems to be the case with almost every social security bill which comes before the chamber. Some of these concerns we raise often in the Senate, but others are specific to the bill.

I will make a comment at this point about the most important part of the bill—namely, the new deeming structure for those people receiving a social security pension which is affected by their investments. All senators would recall the extraordinary difficulties created by the previous approach to assets and income testing for this group in the community. I am sure that the experience in my office of confused and angry people ringing or writing to complain about the system is shared by all other senators.

The government announced this change in the budget in May this year to almost universal acclaim. Since then that sense of welcome for this new structure has not changed even though people have reservations. Certainly, the Greens welcomed the budget announcement as not only a move towards more equitable arrangements but also a sign of the government's commitment to simplifying the social security system.

I will raise one niggling complaint which is not related to the bill but to the explanatory memorandum. I have mentioned this on previous occasions. The explanatory memorandum appears to be used as a propaganda tool rather than as a technical document. Page 4 of the explanatory memorandum states:

SPEECH.PARA: Most social security recipients will be unaffected by extended deeming.

At first glance that statement is quite straightforward and without flaw. However, the fact is that every pensioner with investments will be affected. They may not have the amount of their pension changed, but the Department of Social Security will need to measure their investments to ascertain whether or not the rate of their pension will alter. I make this point because of the significance of the explanatory memorandum in the legal system.

PARA.TAB: While the particular paragraph is unlikely to ever be crucial in a court case, I have referred on a number of occasions to the lack of precision that is creeping in. In case those comments should cause any concern to people who may be listening to this debate, I am informed by the department that very few people will be adversely affected by the changes. I commend the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin) for his continued commitment to simplifying measures such as this. No doubt some of the technicalities will receive extended discussion in the committee stage.

Another matter in relation to this change, and one of greater substance than the one I have just mentioned, is the lack of a legislative framework establishing an assets assessment structure. It is one thing to say that from now on investments held by pensioners will be deemed to be earning a certain level of income, but it is not a complete measure without telling people when their investments will be valued. As was pointed out to me by the Welfare Rights Centre, it could lead to the absurd situation where two pensioners, neighbours even, could have identical investment portfolios valued quite differently because of different valuation dates.

I have been assured by the minister's office that there will be a way of adjusting that administratively rather than legislatively by eventually looking at six-monthly intervals of March, July and September. That makes me somewhat uneasy as it would seem that a change as significant as this one would be best brought about by means of the most certain powers available. I would appreciate some further comment about that from the minister responsible at an appropriate time in the debate.

Before I move on from schedule 1, there is another matter that I believe needs to be raised. I refer honourable senators to proposed section 1073 in clause 28 which deals with certain amounts taken to be received over 12 months. This is, by and large, a carryover of the existing provision 1074 of the act. It is a measure which appears in similar form in the act as it was in the 1987 and 1988 acts, but was changed in the plain English version of the act which came into effect in 1991.

As I indicated, there was a change in the 1991 act. It appears to be minor and has not resulted in any change in the department's treatment of income received by pensioners. However, the change, which removed the words `of income' after the word `amount' could have significant implications should the department, under pressure from a future government, choose to read the section on the basis of its apparent meaning. That meaning could be used to treat gifts given to pensioners as income over a 12-month period with a potential reduction in pension. I acknowledge that this interpretation has not been put on the section up till now, but I can see no barrier to such a move. It could even be suggested that this section could stand in the way of pensioners receiving Lotto prizes. Hence, we will be putting in an amendment to clarify this in the committee to restore the words `of income' to section 1073.

Schedule 2 of the bill makes another welcome change to the act in that it will simplify life for certain people who are on unemployment related payment from DSS. Doing away with people having to move on to sickness allowance if they are unable to fulfil the requirements of an activity test due to ill-health makes good sense and will hopefully reduce the stress on staff and clients alike.

Another welcome change is the amalgamation of jobsearch and newstart. I recall very clearly in 1991 that various groups in the community thought the separation of unemployment benefit into a number of payments was an unnecessary complication. So it is encouraging to see that the government has now chosen to reverse at least part of that move.

I cannot, however, be so congratulatory of the government about the changes to the mature age allowance. It seems that schedule 6 of the bill is an admission of failure. The mature age allowance was introduced, if I recall correctly, as a temporary measure to assist certain older unemployed people during a period of crisis in the economy. It was put into place with a sunset clause to reinforce that view from the government. Schedule 6 removes the sunset clause and puts the mature age amount in place permanently. More significantly, this measure gives the lie to the government's recent move to raise the pension age for women.

We now have the ludicrous situation where a woman, who in years gone by would have moved onto an age pension at age 60 and who after recent changes would have to continue in the work force at that stage in life, will now be eligible for a pseudo pension in the form of the mature age allowance at age 60. Naturally, the Greens will not be opposing this measure but we would be happier if the government would be frank enough to acknowledge the reality of what it has created here—a Clayton's pension.

In my concluding remarks on this bill, I draw the attention of honourable senators and to anyone who may be listening that this measure is accompanied by the usual tax file number requirements. We will continue to raise our concerns about the use of the tax file number in ways which were never countenanced at the time of its introduction. It is history now that the government was taken right through the courts and defeated in the case of Mr John Malloch and has since sought to use extraordinary sophistry to satisfy its desire to make TFNs compulsory for social security clients while also satisfying the concerns of the Privacy Commissioner. While I have indicated some of our concerns—no doubt, we will discuss more in the committee stage—I wish to indicate that the Greens will be supporting this bill in spite of those concerns.

We also welcome the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Carer Pension and Other Measures) Bill 1995, which is primarily making a number of changes to the career pension provisions of the act. We hope to contribute to that process of simplification to which the minister has committed himself. However, there are some changes which aren't welcome. I wish to comment on some of those changes and flag some of the amendments which the Greens (WA) will be putting to the chamber in the committee stage.

Schedule 2 of the bill sets out changes in relation to the Child Care Act 1972 and to the data-matching program. The changes are quite extraordinary. In the first place, the changes will enable the government to require recipients of child-care assistance to provide tax file numbers. I say `require' deliberately because the government seems less and less inclined to hide the fact that it requires people to provide tax file numbers, in spite of the Privacy Commissioner's concerns.

I have mentioned often enough that the legislative circumlocutions which are being employed to keep the Privacy Commissioner at bay rate amongst some of the most outrageous displays of sophistry seen in recent times. In fact, the tax file number provisions in the Social Security Act rank alongside the government's insistence that the boat people in Port Hedland and Curtin are free to go any time they please. But let us look at the bill we are discussing here.

In this case, the requirement to provide a tax file number has a potentially more worrying aspect to it; namely, the need for a provider of child care to satisfy themselves that a child-care relief claimant has provided DSS with their tax file number. I am assured by the minister's office that the department would give the child-care provider the necessary information about their clients so that there can be no question of the claimant having to give their tax file number to someone other than the department. That sounds fine, until something goes wrong.

There are two aspects about this measure which concern me. The first is the possibility that, through some clerical or administrative error, a child-care provider will be given a list of client names with their tax file number listed. The second worrying aspect is that, at some point in the future, this government or some other government will decide that, since the child-care provider already has to be satisfied about the client's tax file number, why not save the client more time and trouble by putting the onus on collecting the TFN on the child-care provider?

From my reading of this bill, such a change could be done administratively with no legislative change necessary. That scenario will probably meet with derision from the government, but the framework is set in the bill already. But there is more, as they say.

Child care recipients will be required to provide their tax file numbers for a most novel reason—so that the data-matching program can be run effectively. The TFN is being extended once again. It used to be just a means of tackling fraudulent claims; now it is necessary to make sure that another form of government intrusion can be properly exercised, efficiently exercised. The Greens (WA) will oppose these measures.

But schedule 2 was also to have removed the sunset clause and thus allow the data-matching program to continue indefinitely. I understand that the government and the opposition have agreed to an amendment which would see the sunset clause extended by a further three years rather than abolished. The Greens will support that proposal.

The explanatory memorandum tells us that this is because the program has not yet saved the government the amounts originally estimated for it. How extraordinary! I seem to recall that, when the data-matching program was introduced, there were any number of commentators in the community who said that the government's estimates of the potential savings were hopelessly over optimistic. Those commentators have been shown to be correct time and time again.

May I quote some figures to the chamber. These figures are `direct' savings. I realise that the government will probably respond by saying, `But there are lots of indirect savings which can't be measured'—the unassailable argument of those who cannot prove their assertions.

In 1990-91 the savings estimate was $65 million and the actual figure was nil with costs of $8 million. In 1991-92 the savings estimate was $290 million and the actual figure was $25 million with costs of $14 million. In 1992-93 the savings estimate was $300 million, and the actual figure attained was $70 million with costs of $14 million. In 1993-94 the estimated savings again were $300 million and the actual savings were $80 million with costs of $16 million.

It seems the government is guilty of a massive understatement when it says in the explanatory memorandum to this bill that the program has not achieved the savings estimated at this time. The estimates, we know, are becoming more modest. Over the next five years, the program is expected to save $436 million at a cost of $70 million. I think it is fair to say that the figures pale when compared with the original estimates we were given.

Without wanting to become too speculative, I wonder why the savings have never matched expectations and why, in the face of such failure, the government still insists on having more of the same. Why widen the net each time the data-matching program comes up in legislation? I offer two comments to this.

The first is that perhaps the government thinks that by widening the net it will eventually bring about the savings it wants. I wonder, though, how many more people in the community will be prepared to put up with the intrusion and the sense of never being trusted by their government. The second flows from that and puts a question to the government: has it ever dawned on those in power that perhaps the Australian people are more honest than the government gives them credit for? Is it possible that the reason the savings are not there is that there simply is not the rorting of the system going on which the government would like us to believe exists in order to justify the intrusions that it is making?

The provision in the bill for a reduced reporting regime for the program is also of concern as it will lower the level of scrutiny of the program by the parliament. In light of the inability of the program to achieve the savings touted for it, which amounts to a failure in the government's eyes, why should the parliament accept a lower level of accountability on the part of the agencies involved?

As annual reports will still be provided to the Privacy Commissioner under the new rules, why shouldn't those same reports be required to be presented to the parliament? I foreshadow that the Greens will put an amendment to that effect. We have other amendments. They relate to rent assistance, the guardian allowance, bank accounts and prison penalties. Because of the time, I will not enlarge on any of those except the last one.

I wish to comment on the note that has been put in schedule 23 of the bill which accompanies each prison penalty clause in the Social Security Act. The note currently draws the reader's attention to the Crimes Act, as does the proposed new note. The new note will make more explicit the point that imprisonment is not the only option open to the courts in sentencing. Honourable senators would be aware that this is an issue which is very close to my heart and that removing the prison penalties has become something of a personal crusade of mine. I have raised the matter often. Indeed, at every opportunity the Social Security Act has been the subject of amending legislation, I have put amendments seeking to remove the prison penalties entirely.

It is interesting that this matter should come up in this session when we have recently debated a similar matter in relation to the Family Law Reform Bill, where the government was prepared to support removing a prison penalty and replacing it with a fine. The Greens will be putting an amendment to remove these penalties. In light of the Family Law Reform Bill debate, we hope we will gain the support of the Senate on this occasion. Again, as with the other bill, the Greens (WA) will not oppose this bill but will put amendments to the Senate in the committee stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be speaking today on the Employment Services Amendment Bill. This bill is included in a group of `related' bills. I do not understand why this bill is being taken cognately with social security and veterans' affairs legislation when the social security legislation has more to do with the Student and Youth Assistance Amendment (Youth Training Allowance) Bill (No. 3).

PARA.TAB: The Student and Youth Assistance Amendment (Youth Training Allowance) Bill (No. 2) is paired in the same legislative fashion with the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Carer Pension and Other Measures) Bill, yet they are taken separately in the parliamentary program. It might seem convenient, but I would think that if you are going to pair `related' bills they ought to somehow be related to each other.

I will deal with the Employment Services Amendment Bill in parts to discuss the various elements of it. Part 1 includes items 1 to 5, and that is the CES notification that participants can join case management. The Greens have no problem with this section of the bill. Instead of two letters going out about case management—one letter to notify that a person has become a participant in limbo waiting for a case management place and the other letter to offer them a place in case management—the latter correspondence will be the first correspondence. This seems fine and an administrative simplification.

Part 2, items 6 to 10, relates to the treatment of seasonal and part-time workers under case management. Seasonal and part-time workers will be treated the same as full-time workers in that they will have to wait 18 months as an unemployed person before they can get access to case management services. The problem is that the part-time worker needs to be working part-time for only 13 weeks before they are knocked off the case management participant lists. There should be more certainty here.

This has more benefits for department statistics fudging than for the people themselves. They may still have a need for case management services to find more permanent work if they are looking for it and if that is their personal goal. It is, however, good to see that the government is not fixed in the opinion that full-time work is the ultimate goal, when it may not be the individual's goal to find full-time work, nor would it be a realistic goal under current labour market conditions.

Part 4 relates to the amalgamation of jobsearch and newstart allowances. That involves items 12 to 56. I have to question whether the amalgamation of these two allowances is a public relations exercise to cover up the extent of long-term unemployment in this country. Having two different allowances is one way of delineating who was long-term and who was short-term unemployed even if the definitions kept changing—that is, whether long-term unemployment meant either 12 months or 18 months of unemployment.

It is also important to have two allowances to target special services to those with greater needs. Newstart recipients have been able to access more vocational education and training services in the past to meet their greater vocational needs. I hope the government will give priority to the long-term unemployed in its provision of staff, resources and funding.

To a large extent case management has been a tool to provide the appearance of the creation of jobs which were really training. Case management's purpose was to move the long-term unemployed for 16 weeks into either training or subsidised employment, which took them off newstart for a period long enough for them to fall out of the long-term unemployment category. Upon returning to unemployment they would return to the jobsearch payment instead of newstart.

This process has the ability to skew the unemployment statistics and make it look as though the long-term unemployed are being helped. This then leaves the case management system to deal with `creaming' off the work-ready who were going to be picked up by the labour market anyway. Then the government can claim unemployment is falling and can cut huge amounts of spending from labour market programs.

My last comments relate to items 20 to 22 of the Employment Services Amendment Bill. It is good to see that the government is being flexible with its eligibility criteria for a jobs compact in that people can still be treated as being on newstart if they have been unemployed for 12 months and working or training for a 13-week period. So all in all we think that unemployment by mirrors is what is going on and continues to go on. We will be looking very carefully at the bill and its consequences to see what actual outcomes result.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen The Hon N.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a few brief comments before we go into committee. Firstly I note there are a significant number of amendments to be considered in committee from the Australian Democrats, the Greens and the opposition. That is one of the reasons why I do not intend to speak for very long. I note that the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Carer Pension and Other Measures) Bill is an important measure. It implements the initiatives announced in our 1995 budget and it aims to make the system simpler and more consistent. This, flowing on from the budget measures, will mean a better deal for people caring for others in the community as well as for those receiving that care.

PARA.TAB: This bill will ensure that a person who cares for another person may qualify for a carer pension even if the caree is not in receipt of a social security or veterans' affairs pension or a social security benefit. It is a very important principle. With the pressures that carers face, the very deep and significant difficulties that they have, both personal and financial, we think this is an important measure.

There are a number of other matters in this legislation. They have been adequately covered by the speakers in their various contributions. It is important to move into the committee stage as soon as possible and, hopefully, pass this legislation before we finish on Friday.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (CARER PENSION AND OTHER MEASURES) BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that Senator Sherry's response was fairly meagre. Consequently, I have been caught a little short. Madam Chairman, could you please tell me which part of the bill we are dealing with?
—We are dealing with the bill as a whole, starting at schedule 1.

—This bill will provide the Secretary to the Department of Social Security with greater discretion in dealing with customers who have travelled overseas without a departure certificate. As the explanatory memorandum says, it will allow the secretary to make a decision as to whether the person has remained qualified for a payment for a period of up to 18 months despite not having fulfilled the normal departure requirements.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Democrats welcome the granting of this discretion but we believe that decisions made with it should be open to appeal. We will be opposing items 30, 31, 32 and 33 of schedule 1 and have drafted an amendment to it to ensure that these decisions can be reviewed by an ARO, by the SSAT and by the AAT. I imagine that the number of people affected by these provisions will be very small and, as such, I do not envisage any administrative difficulties in allowing this very important and worthwhile review. I foreshadow that I will move Democrats amendment No. 2:

TALK.START.PARA: —In dealing with schedule 1 it would be appropriate to deal with items 30, 31, 32 and 33, to which Senator Woodley has just spoken. So the question is that items 30 to 33 inclusive be agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be opposing schedule 3, page 57, item 3. I will explain the reasons why the Democrats are firmly committed to opposing this item. The item relates to the earnings credit scheme. This scheme allows unemployed people to earn a limited amount of outside income without affecting their social security entitlements. It is a very good scheme.

PARA.TAB: The problem is that the government wishes once again to tighten the availability of this scheme. I noticed that a couple of speakers in the debate in the House of Representatives said that the scheme is designed to allow unemployed people who have very high levels of income for a couple of weeks to spread that income over a longer period so that their unemployment payment is not affected. That really is not what it is about. The scheme only allows a modest amount of extra income to be offset under the income test in the fortnight in which that income is earned.

Currently only between six and seven per cent of jobsearch and newstart allowance recipients are making use of the scheme. I believe that there are a couple of reasons for that. Firstly, it is somewhat complicated to calculate exactly what the effect is going to be on a person's entitlement. Let me give a prime example of this that I gave last night in my speech in the second reading debate. I have a very good friend who completed a PhD about 18 months ago. He has been seeking full-time employment ever since. He has only been able to get part-time employment, so the scheme is of interest to him. However, despite the assurances of the CES, when he did accept a four-week casual employment position he discovered at the end of the four weeks, because of the complicated calculations, et cetera, that he actually lost quite a considerable sum of money by working over that four-week period. So you can see the problem.

The second problem with the scheme was one that I warned about when it was first set up—that is, conditions that we have placed on the scheme are so restrictive that it simply is not very useful for people. Fortunately, one of those restrictions will be removed by this bill, so I give a tick to the minister for that. That is the rule that says that earnings credit cannot be assessed in the fortnight where the person's income is over the income test cut-out. This would be a wonderful reform—half a tick actually—except that at the same time the government is seeking to save around $30 million from the scheme by restricting the amount that can be offset to just $50 per week. The earnings credit scheme available to the unemployed is already less generous than the scheme for age pensioners, which allows pensioners to offset up to $1,000 of income in a fortnight and which the recent ageing agendas review said should be made more generous.

Further, the whole push behind the Working Nation reforms was to remove disincentives for people to take on any work opportunities available to them. This move is in the opposite direction. So it is not Working Nation that we are now really dealing with. If we place highly restrictive conditions on the earnings credit scheme, the unemployed simply are not going to make use of it. That would be a great shame. The effect of that will be twofold. Firstly, the unemployed will not take up those work opportunities which may have given them a foot in the door to full-time employment and, secondly, because of this the government will be faced with higher social security outlays. For these reasons, the Democrats will be opposing that part of the bill which seeks to limit to $100 the amount of earnings credit that can be used in any one fortnight.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Woodley said, this bill seeks to limit the maximum amount of earnings that may be disregarded as income through the use of the earnings credit balance from the current maximum of $500 per fortnight to $100 per fortnight. We will not be supporting that amendment.

—The government opposes this amendment. Senator Woodley, I am always pleased to get a tick from you, even if it becomes a half tick in the course of your comments. The legislation before the parliament proposes a number of changes to the earnings credit scheme. They have been incorporated into a package. You cannot just look at one of these without looking at the others. There is a change over a number of things that we hope will be of assistance to people. Amending one part—in this instance, the $100 limit—has an effect on the viability of the other components. Although we acknowledge that the measure will result in savings, it also removes a number of inefficiencies and areas of criticism with the current scheme.

PARA.TAB: The important area where change was necessary was to ensure that persons who were in regular casual work should be provided with some incentive to receive a reasonable rate of jobsearch and newstart allowance over an extended period. There has been a concern that where people have the opportunity to undertake regular, casual or part-time work, they only receive, in effect, a one shot benefit from the scheme. The proposed changes will better target those persons by allowing their earnings credit balance to be used over a longer period.

As an example: following the July 1995 income test changes, a person with an earnings credit balance of $300 who is paid at the single rate—currently, $310.50 a fortnight—and is regularly receiving $300 per fortnight from casual employment, would receive a one-shot benefit that would ensure that the person received the maximum benefit in the fortnight. For the next two pay periods, the person's payment would be reduced to $158.50 in each fortnight. Over the three pay periods, the person would receive $627.50.

Under these modified arrangements, the earnings credit would be available to the person over the three pay periods and that person would receive three equal payments of $228.50, or a total of $685.50 over a comparable period. On those figures that is a benefit of almost $60 over those three pay periods. The difference would be caused by the combined result of the current changes to the rate and method of accrual of earnings credit.

The changes will better assist low and moderate income earners. The scheme will benefit a person who has regular earnings up to $160 because the modified arrangements will provide the person with an effective free area of $160; that is, $100 offset against earnings credit balance, plus the person's $60 free area. The losers under these arrangements will be those persons who have an earings credit balance with one-off earnings.

The savings measure was necessary to put into effect the changes required to remove the inefficiencies and to correct the other anomalies. The cost of the earnings credit amendments included in this measure, such as allowing access to free areas, and the use of and accrual of the balance in the same fortnight, could not be covered if the $100-limit was touched in isolation.

The earnings credit scheme has been modified in a way that will produce savings to the government, but at the same time will allow a person to use their earnings credit balance longer. Persons in receipt of regular casual earnings will be better off under the proposed arrangements. I am not sure that I have persuaded Senator Woodley, but I have to say that Senator Woodley has not persuaded me.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Minister, during the 1993 election campaign Mr Keating promised not to increase taxes. He said, `What I am promising is not to put up taxes.' ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This morning the Guangdong Higher People's Court brought down its decision on Mr Peng's appeal; it was a decision to uphold the Intermediate People's Court's sentence of 28 September. It will be recalled that Mr Peng had been found guilty on two charges and convicted as follows: for unauthorised seizure of company funds of 290,000 renminbi, which is about $A48,000, he was sentenced to 15 years imprisonment with a supplementary sentence of deportation; for embezzlement of company funds of $HK800,000, which is about $A133,000, he was sentenced to three years imprisonment. Sixteen of the total 18 years were enforced imprisonment. The courts also ordered the confiscation of the 290,000 renminbi. That sentence, as I say, has been confirmed.

PARA.TAB: Naturally, the Australian government is extremely disappointed at this outcome, not least because of the various apparent anomalies that were involved in the legal process, which anomalies were primarily the subject of the grounds of appeal in this matter.

We have previously made clear our hope that China would take a course of, first of all, granting clemency and then immediately at the very least deporting Mr Peng. I did that most recently in my discussion with Foreign Minister Qian Qichen at the APEC ministerial meeting in Osaka. I will be repeating that request in the light of this decision.

Of course, the Australian government will continue to lend Mr Peng every due consular support. Any further possible legal action in this case is for Mr Peng and his lawyers to pursue. I think it is well understood that the Australian government is not able to involve itself in the legal processes of another sovereign country and does not have the capacity to intervene in Chinese judicial proceedings.

What we can do is make our concerns known to the executive level of government and we have certainly done that on multiple occasions through the duration of this unhappy case. We have in fact taken over 100 separate actions to promote a resolution of Mr Peng's case, of which well over 30 have been representations at very senior levels of the Chinese government. For example, at the same time as I made representations to Foreign Minister Qian Qichen at the APEC ministerial meeting, the Prime Minister raised his concerns about the case with the Chinese President, Jiang Zemin, in Osaka. As recently as yesterday I made further representations to the visiting Chinese National People's Congress delegation led by Vice-Chairman Wang Bingqian.

As I said, the government is extremely disappointed with the court verdict. We will be repeating our appeal for clemency on a number of grounds—the circumstances of his initial removal from Macau, Mr Peng's already lengthy detention of around two years, the state of his health, the limited access that he has had to medical attention during his detention, the length of his sentence, and its effect on his young family. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction. Minister, what, if anything, do you intend to do for small business in Queensland in the light of today's Yellow Pages small business index survey that found overall Queensland small business people perceive the state's economy as being in recession with only a net 14 per cent expressing any confidence in business activity over the next 12 months?

—First of all, I want to draw attention to the Yellow Pages survey. As I said last week, when they did a special survey on attitudes to state and federal governments, it is a credible survey; I continue to say so. I continue to say it about the survey that came out today. No matter whether it has good or bad news, I always acknowledge that the sampling methods of the survey are quite reasonable. I do acknowledge that that survey out today did show that Queensland, as you said Senator Macdonald, for business confidence prospects in the next 12 months was the lowest, at 14 per cent, which is far too low and does indicate that there are problems with small business confidence and growth prospects in that state.

PARA.TAB: It is a national survey and, as Mr Marsden commented in his statement and on radio today, overall, small business in Australia is more confident about 1996 than they were and have been about 1995. I think, overall, the survey shows a confidence in small business that is improving. I don't beat about the bush; in Queensland there is a weakness in confidence. Mr Marsden also apparently said today in remarks that one of the reasons for the decline in confidence in small business has been the decline in population growth to Queensland from other states. TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. I appreciate Senator Schacht's advice, but I can read the book myself, thank you. I know that information. You have had two minutes now. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer and refers to the City Link tollway project in Melbourne. I refer to comments by Premier Jeff Kennett that City Link is only viable as a project because of the underpinning provided by the federal government's infrastructure borrowing tax concessions of up to $600 million. Minister, will you concede that it is your tax system which has made tollways an inevitable infrastructure choice, given that they are extraordinarily profitable for private operators? Isn't it true that in New South Wales Premier Bob Carr could not buy out the private tollway operators because he could not afford to compensate them for the loss of these tax concessions? While it might suit you politically to try to wash your hands of any responsibility for making City Link possible, it is your responsibility, isn't it, to make sure that tax concessions which you provide are not used to steamroll both environmental and local planning processes?

—The tax concessions we provide—and I presume what Senator Kernot is referring to here goes to the development allowance—are independent of and operate on the assumption that the particular project, in this case an infrastructure development tollway, meets the environmental regulatory standards that are required. Those standards have to be met for the project to proceed in the first place. Let me deal with the first part of the question in that way.

PARA.TAB: The second part of the question was a bit confused. Let me spell out what the Development Allowance Authority does so that you can see that this is an arms-length transaction by the government. The Development Allowance Authority Act 1992 requires that when a valid application for an infrastructure borrowing certificate has been lodged the authority must issue a certificate if the application meets the criteria of the act.

The criteria of the act include the commerciality of the borrower and the borrower's corporate structure; the borrowing and use of the moneys borrowed; the ownership and the use of the facilities; and whether a law exists restricting or prohibiting the operation of other facilities in competition with the approved facility. In this case, the Melbourne City Link tollway, the responsibility will be the same. The responsibility for the infrastructure borrowing certificate process is primarily a matter for the Development Allowance Authority. If the statutory criteria outlined above are met, a certificate must be granted.

Under the existing legislation, the sole power for a minister to intervene in the process is where the Treasurer may direct the authority not to accept applications during a specified period. This can occur where the Treasurer is informed by the authority that the cost to revenue of approved applications has reached the limit set in the regulations.

The other question asked of me by Senator Kernot was: do our tax arrangements drive an inevitability of tollways? It was that question or a question of some such nature as that. I do not think that contention has been made. Until I heard this question I did not think it had been made before.

There is a wider question at the back of all of this. Australians obviously require and do demand a high quality public infrastructure to be provided. At the same time, Australians require and do demand a low taxing base in order to fund public infrastructure. So, when you have private investment heading into the provision of public infrastructure or state governments putting aside massive parts of their own expenditure priorities to fund public infrastructure, recovery of the cost of that means increasingly that we will be looking at projects where there may be tollways or infrastructure provided simply straight off the public purse.

It is the demand for the provision of high quality infrastructure and the requirement by the public to keep tax levels at the lowest possible level that are driving this process. This means that, where funding for infrastructure can be provided by users, that is an option that can be considered at state government level. It is not the structure of taxation that is driving it. But I do repeat my threshold point, which was in answer to the last part of your question: such a project has to meet the environmental criteria under the appropriate regulatory authority in order to qualify for application.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, Senator Faulkner told us yesterday about the environmental criteria. The fact is that the environmental testing has been done on the original proposal, not this one. The question I want to ask you too is that you list all of those criteria of the Development Allowance Authority, but nowhere do you talk about the criterion of trampling over environmental and local government planning processes. Isn't this really about politics? Would it be too cynical to say that this is about making sure Jeff Kennett gets the blame while the ALP gets an advantage in about half a dozen marginal seats affected by this tollway?

—I think the answer to what is really a rhetorical question is yes. My advice is, since the final negotiations have been completed for this tollway, it has thrown up a number of anomalies that the federal government is concerned about—things like the tariffs, the cost of use of the tollway, traffic routing on parallel streets and things of that nature.

PARA.TAB: I go back to what reasonably seems to be your preoccupation with this question, the environmental elements of tollway or freeway construction, and repeat: such a project would need to meet the requirements of the regulatory authorities in terms of getting an environmental clearance. When it does, then it is in a position for the other mechanisms for support to be checked in. That includes, if it meets the criteria of the Development Allowance Authority, Development Allowance Authority assistance.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Only a few months ago Shaping the nation stated, `The Accord has brought a new era in industrial harmony and a better deal for workers.' In June this year, on signing Accord Mark VIII, Martin Ferguson said, `Australia is a better Australia today because of the Accord process.' Less than six months later, as he leaves this sinking ship, such identities as Martin Ferguson blame the Accord for contributing to the Weipa dispute and for failing to deliver real wages growth and, in particular, rising living standards. When one of the principal architects of the much vaunted Accord has now lost faith in the process, why should Australians take any notice of your industrial relations policy which has perpetrated such a cruel hoax on ordinary workers over the last 12 years of Labor government?

—I have never heard any suggestion that Martin Ferguson, or anyone else, is wanting to resile from his commitment to Accord Mark VIII. It would be most surprising if he did because the benefits that have been delivered by that Accord process over the years have been manifest. Since 1983, underlying inflation has fallen from 10.5 per cent to 2.5 per cent. Profit share has been restored. Real unit labour costs have fallen by 8.6 per cent and, as a result, our international competitiveness in terms of labour costs has improved by nearly 39 per cent.

PARA.TAB: Employment has risen over that period by around two million. Real household disposable income has risen by 42 per cent. Fundamental workplace reforms have been achieved through the awards, union structures and work practices. The general level of industrial disputes has been extremely low by historical standards over the life of the Accord—the average number of working days lost per thousand employees is 66 per cent lower than it was over the period of your previous coalition government.

Some 5,754 enterprise agreements as at last month have been formalised by the AIRC, covering around 58 per cent of federal award workers. The levels of assistance in health, education and child care have increased significantly in that context, achieving levels that would have been unimaginable when you lot were last in government in the early 1980s.

What we have achieved in the industrial relations context as well as all that is a more decentralised wages system by supporting workplace bargaining as the main vehicle for wage increases. We want to preserve that right of workplace bargaining—we have made no bones about that. Retirement incomes have been enhanced through employer, government and employee superannuation contributions.

What we have now got with Accord Mark VIII is a new Accord including a commitment to create in excess of 600,000 additional jobs. We have an Accord which will contribute to sustaining the underlying inflation rate at between two and three per cent on average over the cycle. We have a new Accord which allows for safety net adjustments to continue to be available to workers who have been unable to implement enterprise bargains. We have a commitment to further simplify awards in the future, which is of some real utility to business. We have support under the latest version of the Accord for the phased introduction of a requirement for employees to contribute three per cent of their earnings to superannuation by the year 2000.

That is a phenomenal list of achievements for workers, business and the whole community which have been achieved through the Accord process and which are the envy of every other developed country in the world. You travel anywhere, Senator Woods, in Europe or North America and ask whether they would like something like this and the answer is yes. Have they been able to achieve it and have they been able to deliver returns like that? The answer is no. Eat your heart out!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy in his capacity as the minister responsible for energy reform. Can you inform the Senate about the practical progress towards the COAG endorsed competitive electricity market in southern and eastern Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to say I can. What I can tell the Senate today—and this relates to an earlier question that was asked by the opposition—will be very warmly received by small business and big business, all business, and consumers. It is pleasing that, in the face of two weeks of flim-flam and sideshows from the opposition, this government is continuing to make real progress with micro-economic reform in this country.

PARA.TAB: Over the last few years, state and Commonwealth energy ministers, officials and the National Grid Management Council, chaired by Mr John Landels, have been advancing this process. As a result of a further meeting of ministers in Brisbane last night, I can now inform the Senate that we are firmly on track to achieve this reform by the target date of September 1996. I can advise the Senate best by quoting from the first two paragraphs of a statement that was issued today on behalf of all energy ministers. It states:

ANSWER.PARA: Commonwealth, state and territory energy ministers have agreed to begin the implementation phase of the national electric market.
The decision was taken at a meeting of federal and state ministers in Brisbane last night.

The Commonwealth and the states involved—New South Wales, Victoria, Queensland, South Australia, Tasmania and the ACT—have committed themselves to the early establishment of the two key market institutions required for the operation of the market—the National Electricity Market Management Company, NEMMCO, and the National Electricity Code Administrator, NECA.

PARA.TAB: In spite of the fact that the Commonwealth itself, which does not manage the delivery of electricity, will not have a place on either of those bodies, the Commonwealth has contributed $4 million to the establishment cost—that is, one-third of the cost of setting the companies up. Detailed company arrangements for these bodies can now be determined and the appointment of the director has now commenced.

At the meeting last night in Brisbane, the Commonwealth, New South Wales and Victoria signed a memorandum of understanding to establish a joint venture for the information systems and market communications infrastructure required for the commencement of the market, pending the full operation of NEMMCO. The MOU signing means that we are now irrevocably set on the path to a national electricity market. As of now, contracts for the development of market software and hardware systems can be entered into.

This meeting was an important milestone in the progress on electricity reform in Australia. It translated at a very practical level the April 1995 COAG commitment to a competitive market into very real action. You cannot overstate the benefits that will come from this reform to both private consumers and business in terms of increased efficiency and lower prices for energy across Australia. The national market will initially encompass a number of physically interconnected jurisdictions such as New South Wales, Victoria and the ACT. All jurisdictions, however, will maintain a close oversight of the arrangements to ensure that it meets their future needs. Other jurisdictions will join after completing the necessary structural reforms and physical connections to the interstate grid.

The market will represent a fundamental change in the structure and operation of the electricity supply industry in Australia and will be of enormous benefit to the nation. I have said before that these reforms and the vigour with which the Commonwealth has pursued them are a further reminder that the government is the real achiever in this country in micro-economic reform and continues to get its runs on the board.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. Is the minister aware that the latest critic of ATSIC is a Victorian police sergeant who has worked with Aboriginal communities for over 20 years, won the inaugural police officer of the year award from Victoria's Aboriginal community justice panel and immediately after receiving the award criticised ATSIC for failing to deliver much needed funds to community level?
—What's his name?

—I will give you his name in a minute. Is the government contemplating any major overhaul of ATSIC and its funding process to ensure that the Aboriginal communities, especially those in remote locations, are equitably and appropriately allocated a share of ATSIC? His name is Sergeant Greg Chandler.
—Does he wear a red hat?
—I don't know.
—The answer to Senator Panizza's question is no.
—Can you tell your colleagues to stop laughing?
—Senator Panizza can look after himself, Senator Macdonald; he doesn't need you. I am not familiar with that particular police officer's criticism of ATSIC.
—Why don't you get a briefing?
—I do not think I will bother; I have enough to do. If Senator Panizza wants to refer the article to me—
—Don't you care?

—It has been so long since the opposition has actually asked a question in here relating to Aboriginal affairs that I cannot remember the last one. The reason I mention that is that all of the questions the opposition does raise in respect of Aboriginal affairs all relate to one thing—that is, criticising Aboriginal organisations. They never stop doing it. They make a life's career out of doing it.

PARA.TAB: ATSIC is a democratically elected organisation, elected by the Aboriginal people of Australia themselves. It fulfils a vitally important role in providing much needed services on the ground. It has many critics, and most of them are non-Aboriginal. Most of them, in my experience as someone who has spent a lot of his life in Aboriginal communities, are people who apply for grants and do not get them. I notice that Senator Panizza is nodding in assent. Before I can give Senator Panizza a considered answer to this question, I would like to examine whether the particular person's concerns are related to individual communities or individual grants.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said that in the question.

—You did say that, did you? I assume in that case it may well be that this person has complained because the particular community with which he has been associated has applied for funding from ATSIC and did not get it. I have to say simply, as someone who represents a constituency, most of the complaints I get about ATSIC are related to that particular problem. I can understand that. It is all part of the democratic process. It is the sort of slings and arrows of outrageous fortune that we have to take from time to time and the same thing applies to ATSIC.

PARA.TAB: The fundamental strength of ATSIC—and it is unlike any other Aboriginal organisation in Australia in this regard—is that it is constituted from a national system of fair and free elections by Aboriginal people across Australia. As a result, I do not think there is any other organisation in Australia that can fairly claim to be as democratically elected as ATSIC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The most scrutinised.
—And, I might add, probably more closely scrutinised than a lot of private companies in this country.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will read you a couple of lines of what Sergeant Greg Chandler had to say:

PARA.TAB: I believe too much ATSIC money is spent on administration and not enough gets to the people on the street.
I see $60 million spending at ATSIC administration and I see youth care being run on donations from the community because they can't get funding.

QUESTION.PARA: I simply ask you, Minister, to tell me: do you really believe that all is well with ATSIC?

TALK.START.PARA: —I can give you a specific response to that particular concern, Senator Panizza, which is easily demonstrated. Telstra has also produced a customer charter detailing in plain English what Telstra's customers are entitled to expect in terms of service. As a first step, Telstra has produced a comprehensive guide to services for the use of customers. Telstra has also developed a new customer complaints and fault management procedure. In addition, steps have been taken in response to the allegation of privacy breaches by Telstra and on the CoT cases. The work on the network development undertakings that have been given by Telstra is close to finalisation. TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook), to a question without notice asked by Senator Crane this day, relating to taxation and fuel excise.

SPEECH.PARA: My question was a very straightforward one to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I asked him to rule out further increases to existing excise on fuels or the extension of excise to other forms of energy, particularly gas. I do not believe that Senator Cook once mentioned in his answer the words `fuel excise' or `tax relating to fuel'. He totally avoided the question that was asked. One can only conclude from that that the intention of the government must be to further increase existing fuel excise with the real possibility of extending it to other forms of energy, in particular gas.

PARA.TAB: I look briefly at the record of this government in terms of its position on fuel excises during its 13 years in government. When we look at petrol we find across-the-board that that has increased from 6.155c to 33.5c per litre. That is almost an increase of 500 per cent; it is an increase of 498 per cent over that period. We see with diesel that once again it is the same situation—from 6.155c per litre to 33.5c per litre. We find that light fuel oil and top crude oil, for example, have increased from zero to 33.5c.

Not only have there been massive increases over that period—and I believe it is very close, if you work through it, to there being on average a 40 per cent excise increase per year—but also there has been a significant extension of the base as far as these taxes are concerned. It highlights very clearly that this government has decided to continue taxing policy or an excise policy that is going to hit rural and regional Australia very hard indeed. It is also going to hit very hard indeed the transport industries.

Coming to a more particular aspect of it: since November 1992, when we were told by the government that it was not going to put taxes up, we find in this instance that excise on petrol has increased from 26.154c to 33.5c and on diesel from 26.154c, or just over 26c, to 33.5c. Then we get to some real crunch times in terms of what has happened since the last election from a government that was not going to put taxes up. We find that the light crude, the kerosenes, the fuel heating and oil, the top crude oil—all fuels that are used extensively in our transport systems and in the railways—have gone from 5.425c to a massive 33.5c in just three years.

I think that highlights very much what the taxing policy of this government is concerned with. Firstly, it is going to continue to increase taxes significantly, particularly in the area of excises, and, secondly, it is going to attack that area of the community that is least able to defend its position in the ballot box. This government is going to hit particularly our productive industries, our primary producers and our mining industries. It is going to kill totally any chance of getting any real decentralisation of industry out into the hinterland or even up the coast—for example, up around Karratha in my state of Western Australia. We should see secondary industry developing up there where there is gas, iron ore and just about every conceivable mineral in large quantities that you can mention.

The point I want to make, in terms of this question I asked today about whether the government would rule out further increases to existing taxes on fuels, is that Senator Cook did not rule them out. In terms of the extension of excise taxes to other forms of energy, particularly to gas, once again he did not rule it out. He did not even address the substance of the question. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

I remember the days in the recent past when Queensland was synonymous with a go-ahead, aggressive, exciting state where there were lots of new businesses, lots of new jobs, and where the economy was booming. But, after six years of state Labor government and 13 years of this mob in office federally, my state of Queensland has gone downhill very quickly.

I remember the days when Gordon Chalk, Bill Knox, Llew Edwards, Mike Ahern and Joh Bjelke-Petersen were treasurers of our state. In those days we Queenslanders could look forward to an expanding economy. You might remember, we used to be the Cinderella state back in the bad old days, after 30 or 40 years of Labor rule. We suddenly became the progressive state, with the mass migration to Queensland being just tremendous.

PETITION.TITLE: Logging and Woodchipping

PARA.TAB: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled
This Petition of the undersigned Australian citizens respectfully points out that:

There is an urgent demand from the majority of Australians for immediate Federal Government intervention, to comply with the United Nations Biodiversity Convention to which Australia is a signatory, and protect the remaining high conservation value forest areas which support flora and fauna unique to Australia.

immediately implement the moratorium clause in the 1992 National Forest Policy Statement, and cease all logging activities in high conservation value forests;

permanently protect in reserves, all old growth, wilderness, and other high conservation value forest areas, under the custodianship of Australian indigenous peoples, in cooperation with local communities, conservation and scientific organisations;
reap only what is sown by utilising readily available plantation timbers for industry needs;
rapidly implement timber industry transition from native forests to plantations, with provision for retraining, redeployment, and compensation if necessary for affected workers and contractors;
restructure the paper and fibre board industries to use annual fibre crops such as kenaf, hemp, cane etc.

create employment incentives to collect seeds, propagate, establish and manage sustainable permaculture-style mixed species timber plantations, on existing cleared and degraded lands, and encourage investment in the growing and marketing of indigenous forest products, such as native fruits, nuts, berries, seeds, oils, and other nutritional and medicinal resources.
develop educational environmental tourism as a sensitively managed industry, in appropriate forest areas, with full respect for Aboriginal cultural heritage and sacred sites; and
further support the above initiatives by the progressive utilisation of defence personnel, resources and funding, to assist rural communities to implement sustainable plantation forestry practices.
