INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The President has received the following letter from Senators Chamarette and Lees.

PARA.TAB: Dear Mr President,

INTERJECT.PARA: Pursuant to standing order 75, I give notice that today I propose to move:

PARA.TAB: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

INTERJECT.PARA: The urgent need for immediate protection of high conservation value forests, the phase out of export woodchipping in native forests and the establishment of an industry transition strategy, to protect workers and secure their future through a transition to the extensive plantation base.

PARA.TAB: More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: The urgent need for immediate protection of high conservation value forests, the phase out of export woodchipping in native forests and the establishment of an industry transition strategy, to protect workers and secure their future through a transition to the extensive plantation base.

SPEECH.PARA: Many members of the public will be well aware of the significance of this issue at this point in the week and also my colleagues in the chamber are well aware that this week the federal cabinet has been meeting to consider the fate of our native forests. Of course that has aroused considerable concern within the community. That is the reason for this matter of urgency debate today.

PARA.TAB: This is a vital time for forests and the outcome of the deferred forest assessment process will be announced on Friday of this week, we are told, as part of the decision that the federal government is making to renew export woodchip licences. This is really the last chance for the government to patch up its very blackened environmental credentials. I believe that the vast majority of the community is justifiably concerned that the government will not take the opportunity that is provided to it to actually take a decisive step in the protection of our high conservation value native forests.

We seek their protection particularly from the depredations of the woodchip industry. The scale and extent of logging of our forests for the woodchip export industry over the last 10 to 15 years has increased so markedly as to cause concern to even the ordinary observer who travels, as is their usual wont in the south-west of Western Australia, to see the beauties of that unique forest area.

The major concern is the extent of the logging, sometimes involving clear-felling of high conservation value forests that are remaining and their use as woodchips. It is particularly ironic at a time when there is a huge stockpile of logs lying in native forest areas and alongside roads and also when there is a clear glut on the market. It is adding insult to injury to be considering the renewal of the licences for export of woodchips at this time.

The particular bill that I introduced in the Senate this week actually had as its focus the protection of Australia's native forests and it deals with the issues we are discussing in this matter of urgency debate. We believe that the community is calling for the government to have the political will to protect old-growth forests, to preserve wilderness, to actually make sure there is no more export of woodchips from native forests in world heritage areas, on the National Estate or on the interim register of the National Estate.

We certainly know the government made a commitment that it would be phasing out export woodchips. We have seen no evidence in that respect. In fact, if the decision goes ahead with only the threatened holding back of 20 per cent as a kind of insurance that the conservation and the deferred forests assessment process will be upheld, it means there is no reduction in the export licences, and that is a disgrace. This is a time when we were promised there would be a total phase-out by the year 2000 and nothing has moved in that regard.

People all around Australia—and I am sure other senators will raise the concerns in their place—are crying out for the protection of high conservation value forests. We desperately want those forests—the jarrah, karri and marri forests of south-west Western Australia—preserved and we want to see the biodiversity of those areas retained.

Those areas represent the last remaining old-growth forests. Some of them were selectively logged many years ago; nevertheless, they remain our last vestige of old-growth forests. The endangered species that live within them deserve and demand protection, and they should be given that protection. We really have to ask this government to show their credentials and prove that they are willing to protect these habitats and preserve the ecosystems and the biodiversity that they maintain for us in this country. This is of national importance.

I am sure that people will raise this issue in relation to the south-east forests, the Gippsland, the Tarkine and other areas, but I make no apology for concentrating on the forests of the south-west section of Western Australia. Approximately 90 per cent of the people of Western Australia sincerely believe that something has to be done to prevent this depredation that has been going on.

There is an urgent need for the immediate protection of high conservation value forests. This protection needs to be in line with not only the Commonwealth government's reserve criteria—which I believe is outlined in the amendment that the government proposes to move to this motion—but also its commitment to the people of Australia.

The government's commitment to the Australian people was to phase out export woodchipping in native forests—not simply in those areas covered by regional forest agreements, as mentioned in the government's foreshadowed amendment, but in the areas that are the remnants of our precious old-growth and heritage forests. Those areas deserve our protection. The community has called on the government to do that and, if the government does not respond to that call, it is falling far short of what it is expected to do. My colleague Senator Margetts will address the transition strategy. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government will not be supporting Senator Chamarette's motion in the form that she has moved it. While it is in its current form, it is not consistent with government policies. I will therefore be seeking leave later to move an amendment to Senator Chamarette's motion. The motion as amended would read:

PARA.TAB: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

SPEECH.PARA: The urgent need for immediate protection of high conservation value forests in line with the Commonwealth Government's reserve criteria, the phase out of woodchipping in native forests not covered by regional forest agreements and the establishment of an industry strategy, to protect workers and secure their future, including through increased utilisation and expansion of the plantation base.
I hope that the amendment to Senator Chamarette's motion will find favour with a majority of senators. That amended motion is now being circulated in the chamber.

PARA.TAB: As amended, the motion effectively describes the parameters of the government's approach to what is a very difficult issue. I think it is very important for everyone who takes an interest in this issue to understand what the government's approach is and what we are trying to achieve in implementing what I know to very many people is an enormously complex process.

We have actually tried to solve the most difficult and contentious environmental issue of recent years. The way we are proposing to do this is by creating a world-class system of reserves to protect our high conservation value native forests and the biodiversity they support and also by ensuring that the forests outside these reserves are managed in a way that is ecologically sustainable.

We are going about this process in a very systematic manner, involving all groups in the community which have an interest in our forests—that is, the industry, the trade unions and, of course, the community groups on both sides of the green divide, if you like. We have set up a group of eminent scientists to make recommendations about what criteria should be used to establish a forest conservation reserve system.

In July, the Commonwealth government approved the criteria that was recommended by those scientists. The Commonwealth's reserve criteria includes the protection of 15 per cent of forests which were in existence at the time of European settlement in Australia, the protection of at least 60 per cent of all the remaining old-growth and up to 100 per cent of rare and endangered old-growth forests, and the protection of at least 90 per cent of all high quality wilderness areas.

When we announced those criteria they were welcomed by both industry and conservation groups. The International Union for the Conservation of Nature praised the criteria. The IUCN said it is an excellent set of criteria which reflects extremely well the current art and science of reserve protected area system design.

As you know, the government is currently considering a range of forest matters, including which of those areas should be deferred from logging pending the conclusion of regional forest agreements. Our objective in delineating the deferred forest areas has been to ensure that those areas are sufficiently extensive to ensure that a forest reserve system can be established through regional forest agreements and meets the Commonwealth's reserve criteria. This is the challenge that the government has set itself and it is the challenge that the government is determined to meet in this debate. The government is committed to the establishment of a world-class conservation reserve system and it will be based on criteria that have been welcomed right across the board.

I will be inviting all those who have an interest in our forests to compare what the Labor government has delivered in terms of forests, as on many other environment issues, with what the coalition has done or might promise to do if it gets around to telling the people of Australia what its policies are. The record of the coalition is pathetic.

We have the Bjelke-Petersen government's appalling record on the protection of the Queensland rainforests. Compare John Fahey's forest policies to Bob Carr's. Look what Ray Groom's government in Tasmania is doing to the Tarkine with the Tarkine Road. Compare Joan Kirner's policies to Jeff Kennett's. Labor's record is outstanding and we are going to maintain our commitment to protecting our high conservation value forests. I seek leave to move the government's amendment in the terms circulated.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: Omit all words after ``urgency'', insert ``The urgent need for immediate protection of high conservation value forests in line with the Commonwealth Government's reserve criteria, the phase out of export woodchipping in native forests not covered by regional forest agreements and the establishment of an industry strategy, to protect workers and secure their future, including through increased utilisation and expansion of the plantation base.''.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on this important motion which has been moved by Senator Chamarette. I foreshadow that I will be moving an amendment to the motion. I do not think it has been circulated at this stage. I will read it out at the end of my address.

PARA.TAB: The Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, Senator Faulkner, is right to tell us that the government has to stand on its record. I fully support that the government has to stand on its record. The reality is that after 13 years, what has the government delivered for the forest industry? Let me put it this way. There is huge uncertainty from both conservationists and the forest industry. This government has also proven to be a champion at the export of woodchips.

The reality is that no government in Australian history has exported more woodchips than the Labor government. No government has done less to set up value adding in Australia than the Labor government. I think Australians are rightly concerned about the volume of woodchips being exported. They believe, as I believe, that far more of these woodchips should be processed in Australia. There is no argument on that score and I am pleased to see some senators across the chamber nodding.

TALK.START.PARA: —We just agree how bad your performance was in Meet the Press.

—We know how bad your performance is, Senator Ray, because after 13 years the forest industry still does not know where it stands. If the press reports are correct, you still have not got the states to sign on. The industry is greatly concerned about the position you have adopted, as is the conservation movement. Senator Ray, we know exactly what you have delivered. What you will continue to deliver is massive uncertainty in this industry. You have had 13 years to get it right.
—Never had it so good while you were the opposition spokesman—one out of 10!

PARA.TAB: In 1992 all the states and the Commonwealth signed on to an agreement. Admittedly, the Tasmanian government came in a little later, but they have signed on to the national forest policy statement. The national forest policy statement calls for a world-class reserve system, which we all support. But what happened? Three years down the track the debate is still continuing. I doubt whether this country is any closer at this stage—if the rumours in the newspapers are correct—to having a settlement in the forests.

I believe all Australians support the position that we must have a world-class reserve system. We must protect our high conservation native forests and we must have certainty in that area. The industry is entitled to seek certainty so that we can have a sustainable timber industry. I regret to say that that is what Labor has utterly failed to deliver. An announcement will be made on Friday. Why Friday? So there can be minimal debate in this chamber and so that there will not be a fear of protests outside Parliament House.

I put it to you, Senator Ray, that as usual you have ducked the central issue. No wonder you want to sneak it out on Friday night so that there will be minimal debate in this chamber about the handiwork of yourself, Mr Keating and Senator Faulkner. Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: Omit all words after "urgency", insert "The urgent need for immediate protection of high conservation value forests, the phase out of woodchips exports from native forests not covered by the regional forest agreements, and the establishment of an industry transition strategy, to protect workers and secure their future through a transition to the extensive plantation base.".

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats will continue to support the matter of urgency proposed by Senator Chamarette and Senator Lees. We do that because there is an immediate need to have protection of our high conservation value forests and there should be a phase-out of export woodchipping of native forests. Chipping was first sold to the Australian community as a way of reducing waste. It was described in that way. It has become a means of creating waste. Any material which is chipped and sold overseas has the potential to become paper pulp, at least in Australia and, of course, other material could find a better use as high grade timber produce. There is no need to export woodchips from Australia.

PARA.TAB: We do need to establish an industry strategy to protect workers to secure their future in the industry and in Australia. It is the Democrats' well-established priority to ensure that our communities act as communities. In other words, if a whole community values a resource and decides to protect it, individuals should not bear those individual costs. The costs should be shared, as should the benefits. Those benefits are not restricted to the aesthetic values; they include all non-wood values of our forests, some of which are the tourist, cultural and historical values and the threatened species within the forests, et cetera.

We support the motion's expression of a need to conduct a transition to the extensive plantation base. Of course, discussion of this is very important. We need to properly utilise those plantations which are now available. There is no justification at all for importing radiata pine into Australia. I am sure honourable senators have noticed one of the longest answers ever before this parliament. On 21 November 70 pages of Hansard, in answer to a question of mine, are devoted to listing the source, quantity and value of radiata pine imported into Australia. We would expect that it is imported from New Zealand, the United States and Canada. But it is also imported from Latvia, Russia, the Netherlands, Norway, the Slovak Republic, Finland and India. There is no need for that. It just illustrates perfectly the need to have a real forest management strategy and a well-considered wood products industry coordination—a policy which worked for this government. We do not have that.

The fact that we have seen a couple of amendments proposed to this motion on the run demonstrates the need for extensive discussion, research and information gathering. The fact that this government had not collated the quantities of timber that have been imported into Australia and presented it in a public form until I asked the question demonstrates to me that the government is making decisions not based on fact but based on political expediency. We should be planting plantations which are unlike the rows of monospecies that we see so much of in Australia today.

There is growing international research, especially from Greenpeace New Zealand, but also from Europe, that multi-species and multi-age cultivations are much more robust and productive and less susceptible to the pests and diseases which affect other monocultures. This transition needs to be carefully planned. It needs to be flexible and it needs to be well advised with statistics. We also need to recognise that what is proposed by the government as a continuation of what exists at the moment cannot be defended. It has produced division and anxiety in the industry, as well as the community which is not directly involved.

There is a range of tree harvesting practices, tree resource type and forestry type covering everything from those pristine, untouched, high conservation value, unique, precious and aesthetically priceless treasures which all Australians would agree need to be protected. There are a range of forest types—whether they be fairly mundane, ordinary land which is often described as scrub, through to land which is shared in an agricultural sense, through to rough grazing and a mixture of agricultural and private forest types to public or private plantation types. These all require a different management style. They cannot be treated just by drawing a couple of lines on maps and then arguing about the extent of a quantum of numbers.

We need to recognise that there is a range of forest management practices which range from clear felling—the slash and burn mentality—right through to what is essentially gardening of individual trees and plantations. In recognising that, we have to ensure that we make allowance in a forest statement and a wood products statement to recognise the opportunities that exist for different management styles and a different range of treatments. That is not recognised in what we are expecting in a couple of days.

I have asked the government for the costs of chipping and the benefits of chipping. The information is not available. We find just today from ABARE—from some figures I have had analysed—that if exports of pulpwood have brought us $564 million, imports of timber have cost us $538 million. We are exporting pulpwood in one form and importing timber which we see used in construction sites around Australia. We do not see a lot of high value quality wood. These figures demonstrate the need for much more research. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion specifically mentions a transition strategy. Why is it important and why has the government crossed it out? It has been continually asked why a low value product has been sought when a high value product could have been used. Frequently there have been interjections across the chamber, `Why would anyone use a tree for a low value product, Senator, when they could make a high value sawlog?' Good question. The answer is: you are talking about labour costs and about volumes versus value minus labour costs.

PARA.TAB: So when you look at the volumes in relation to export woodchips, that is what is sought by the companies involved. We have heard today about the values of the imported products. Therefore, we can see that, no matter how much volume of woodchips we go after, we are never going to have a positive balance of trade at this rate in the way the industry is structured. We must have a transition strategy.

In timber towns in Western Australia people are very dependent on a major industry like a woodchipping industry. Another way of looking at it is that while those towns were produced, and a lot of the time owned, by governments—say, the Western Australian government—the housing, infrastructure and so on was often given to the companies involved. People have lived in those houses for years and years. The company has been more than paid, over and over again, for the value of those houses. Guess what? When those people lose their jobs, not because of the conservation movement but because of the nature of the industry—because it is using more volume of forest and fewer people, and has been doing so at a rate over the last few years—then those people's only options are to leave town or buy one of the houses.

That is something that should be looked into. If industry is saying that it is really concerned about the jobs of workers, then the fact that those workers will have paid many times over for their houses should be taken into consideration. That should be part of any severance package, I believe, when the nature of the industry has caused the retrenchments.

Are the large companies really concerned? What is a transition strategy? I will tell you what it is not. It is not replacing export woodchips when the market for export woodchips tails off with whacking great pulp mills which will continue to rely on the exploitation of old-growth forests. I will get to that later.

We need to look at the people who are currently working in the industry. If we are looking at jobs, we also have to look at what kinds of areas those people could reasonably be retrained in. We have to look at, as I mentioned before, where those people can live and the viability of the towns in which they live. We also have to look at the fact that a lot of the towns in which they live also have other needs for resource security.

To give you an example, the Gloucester Tree in the south-west of Western Australia has been closed. The official reason is that the tree is not safe to climb any more. Many people suspect the real reason is, if you climbed the Gloucester Tree now—which earns the local community something like $8 million a year from people who come and want to look at the area—you would be disgusted with what you saw from the top of that tree.

We had an announcement the other day that a new tree has been opened. They have found another bit of forest which might be able to be looked at from a tall tree. In the future perhaps they will have to change to another tree. That resource, which is necessary for the tourist industry, for small business, for craft industry and for high value industry in that area—creating jobs, not losing jobs—is being taken away from those people. Those jobs are real jobs too.

TALK.START.PARA: —Virtual reality trees.

—Yes, virtual reality trees, as Senator Bell suggests. We have to be honest when we talk about industry and look at the various interests of the industries involved and at job security, if that is what people are really interested in, for the people who have a stake in the forests of Australia.

PARA.TAB: Plantations are an existing resource. We have had copious information about that. In Western Australia agroforestry is an almost untapped reserve of future timber not only for pulp but also for sawlogs and reducing salinity. We have to be looking at these strategies sensibly and we have to take all of this into consideration. We have to talk about the real viability of towns, we have to talk about jobs in a total sense and we have to talk about resource security in its widest sense. If we really do look at those and if we really do look at the actual benefits and cost to our community, then we should make the right decisions. (Time expired)
Amendment (Senator Faulkner's) negatived.
Amendment (Senator Kemp's) negatived.

That the motion (Senator Chamarette's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General:

INTERJECT.PARA: Report No. 12 of 1995-96—Performance Audit—Risk Management by Commonwealth Consumer Product Safety Regulators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a very significant report by the Auditor-General into risk management by Commonwealth consumer product safety regulators. The Auditor-General is a very useful person and his office is of great assistance, particularly in looking at areas where there is the capacity to save taxpayers' money.

PARA.TAB: Every time the opposition says that there is scope for saving money, the government asks, `Where?', in some sort of accusatory way. The fact is that there are many areas—and the Auditor-General keeps pointing them out—where money can and should be saved. This report by the Auditor-General points out yet another area. I hope that the next coalition government will take action, as recommended by the Auditor-General, to save millions of dollars.

According to the Auditor-General in this report, it is conservatively estimated that annual government outlays on medical treatment of consumer product caused injuries and on deaths is between $194 million and $238 million. Clearly, here is a situation where prevention is far better than having to spend hundreds of millions of dollars in governmental outlays—that means taxpayers' money—on medical treatment of injuries and on deaths caused by consumer products either malfunctioning or doing something which they are not supposed to do. The Auditor-General says:

SPEECH.PARA: Expenditure on direct treatment—
that is by the whole of the community, not just the government—
of all consumer product related injury is estimated at $1.4 billion per annum.
As the Auditor says:

These figures illustrate the extent and cost of unsafe consumer products. They also indicate the scope for the Department of Human Services and Health to reduce medical treatment costs through the better adoption of a risk management approach by regulators and increased leadership and coordination by the Department.

Yes, the department could and should be doing more to cut out this horrendous bill, which is not only a bill in financial terms but also an enormous impost in physical terms on those people who are injured or, of course, who suffer death as a result of consumer product failures. The Auditor-General in the report found:
. . . regulators—

that is the whole range of them: governmental authorities charged with regulating various consumer products ranging from ordinary consumer products to therapeutic goods, the Federal Office of Road Safety, the National Food Authority, the Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs and so on—

had not adopted a risk management approach throughout the full range of their operations. Regulators are also not monitoring or evaluating their performance outcomes to ensure consumers are being adequately protected.

Regulators usually focus attention on specific regulatory action rather than coordinated, systematic countermeasures . . . with clearly defined objectives and outcomes. To protect consumers better, they—
the official regulators—

need to adopt risk management principles involving the identification and analysis of injuries, illnesses and deaths related to consumer products; setting priorities; and designing, implementing and evaluating intervention strategies which reduce the human and economic cost of unsafe consumer products.
The Auditor-General goes on:

To reduce consumer product related injuries and deaths, regulators should identify injury causes and interventions. This information is also necessary to target such interventions and assess their effectiveness. The ANAO found that all regulators need to improve their risk identification and analysis as part of their management program.
There is a particular need for more coordinated risk identification and analysis across the Commonwealth and for regulators . . .
It is interesting to note that the report says:
The Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs—
for example—

has not adopted a strategic approach to identifying and analysing consumer product safety risks. The Bureau has acknowledged that its role `has tended to be one of reacting to injuries rather than preventing them'.

There is no doubt that that clearly is an area where the Auditor-General believes, and I think the parliament believes, that there is real scope for far better coordinated activity by the government. In the area of recalling faulty items, the Auditor-General points out:

PARA.TAB: There is scope for all regulators to improve their monitoring and coordinating of voluntary recalls . . . The ANAO found that regulators did not encourage compliance sufficiently with recall codes or ensure that the nature of the hazard and potential consequences were effectively communicated to consumers. As a result, recall effectiveness was impaired.

SPEECH.PARA: He goes on:

PARA.TAB: Only three mandatory recalls of consumer products have ever been ordered. All were requested by the Therapeutic Goods Administration. There were instances where regulators decided that mandatory recalls were necessary but were unable to have mandatory recalls ordered through the Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs. The ANAO considers the Bureau should facilitate the use of mandatory recalls by all regulators to ensure mandatory recalls are ordered when necessary.

SPEECH.PARA: That strikes me as extraordinary—that over all that time these regulators have been in existence there have been only three such mandatory recalls. I might say that the business community has behaved very sensibly and you often see product recalls at the initiative of industry itself rather than mandatory recalls at the request of government. I think that is a very positive point. No doubt the need for intervention may well be limited if the private sector in fact behaves in that kind of responsible way. The Auditor-General in particular looks to the consequences of failing to protect Australian consumers. He says:

PARA.TAB: Australian governments incur significant health costs—

SPEECH.PARA: as I outlined earlier; and that—
Accounting for these costs has only recently become transparent as an item in assessing and managing demand for government health services.

PARA.TAB: A recent report found that injury:

SPEECH.PARA: .is a leading cause of death in Australia, accounting for 7489 deaths in 1992;
.accounts for one in ten hospital episodes and the average length of stay of injury patients is longer than the average of all admissions;
.accounts for a higher percentage of hospital admissions (13 per cent) than either cancer (7 per cent) or cardiovascular disease (8 per cent);
.accounts for a greater percentage of occupied bed days (12 per cent) than cancer (9 per cent) and most other causes;
.contributes to 24 per cent of disability in the community;
.is the principal cause of deaths between the age of 1 and 44; and
.accounted for direct medical costs in 1989-90 of $1170 million, not including costs attributable to medical misadventure.

PARA.TAB: The report found that consumer products were a prime cause of injury. A study commissioned by the ANAO . . . found consumer product-related deaths totalled 4630 in 1991-92.

SPEECH.PARA: So the enormous cost of consumer product-related deaths and injury to the Australian community is enormous. I commend the Auditor-General for examining this matter in the way that he has. It is another instance of those studies which do reveal that there is potential for the cutting of government expenditure, or at least the saving of government expenditure, if proper preventative measures are adopted. It puts the lie once again to the statement continually made by the government that there is no way of further cutting government expenditure. There certainly is and the Auditor-General has pointed out yet another of them.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues, I present the report of the committee entitled Funding and administration of the Family Court of Australia and I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Before speaking specifically to it, I remind the Senate that this is the third in a series of reports prepared by the joint select committee arising initially from a review of the Family Law Act and its operations. Senators will recall that prior to that happening Senator Brownhill was significantly involved in urging senators, the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) and others to become involved in this issue, which was a significant issue in the electorate offices of all of us from the number of constituents who came to us about problems with the court, as they saw it, and about problems with the Child Support Agency.

PARA.TAB: In the initial terms of reference, though, we were restricted to looking at the operation of the court itself and were not asked to look at the Child Support Agency. Of the vast array of amendments—many of which senators have come to know better in recent times as we have debated bills putting into effect some of the recommendations—one of the recommendations was that the act be reprinted and made easier to use. Considering that it all started from what was supposed to be a simple procedure, that was a necessity.

We also recommended that we have an inquiry into the operation of the Child Support Agency—not just the agency itself but the formula that was the basis upon which the agency operated. Nobody was challenging that the legislation was sound. Nobody was challenging the fact that if you parent a child you will contribute to its support as the first line of support, not other taxpayers as the first line of support. We have presented the report in relation to the agency.

Also in the first report we recommended that there be an inquiry into the funding and administration of the court, because so frequently there came up the issue of adequate funding and whether we could do this and whether we could do that—I am simplifying it of course. We felt that we needed to have a look at the funding of the court and to make some comments to the parliament about it.

I am pleased to recognise in the chamber this afternoon Senator Jim McKiernan, the distinguished chairman of the committee when it started. The first report was an excellent one, due to the skill of his chairmanship and the way he went about the inquiry, which was a difficult one. I was sad when he left the committee to go on to bigger things. I certainly enjoyed working with him while he was a part of the committee.

This particular inquiry has had a chequered history. It started during the term of the last parliament, was deferred while we looked into the child support agency, and now it is completed, rather a long time since it was commenced. I recognise the role that Robina Mills played in the life of the committee. When she left in March 1994, Jane Vincent became the secretary. She has worked most diligently, having had a great deal to catch up on.

Claressa Surtees has been acting as secretary for the last few weeks while Jane has been away. I particularly mention David Wallace—legal adviser to the committee and of enormous assistance throughout—Matthew Mason-Cox, Susan Cardell, Jennifer Hughson and Denise Picker. This committee has gone on for a long time and has been hard worked.

In the time available I can refer to only some of the issues in the report. Our conclusion is that the court is adequately funded. We base that in part on the statement the Chief Justice made in 1992 to the effect that funding was adequate to do the existing tasks at existing standards. We felt that was a significant comment.

We believe that the court ought not embark on initiatives without first securing funding. Mechanisms are in place for it to go to the Department of Finance to discuss additional funding from time to time. We were critical of the court's practice of overspending and of the management practices that enabled it to borrow against future funds. In the end, the view of all of us on the committee was that this year the court has been rescued by the Justice Statement. I do not know how it would have coped with its funding situation had the Justice Statement not been put down. That is not a satisfactory situation. As noted in the report, continual borrowing is analogous to a person living on their bankcard, and we have been somewhat critical of that.

We have made some suggestions about the management of the court. We were not impressed with the regional structure that has been established. We feel it is not in the best interests of the court's operation. You would need to read the whole section on management structure to comprehend that view. To just pull bits out would not create the impression that we want to leave.

We dealt with the area of funding in some detail. I want to deal now with an area that flows from that—counselling. We make no specific recommendations about it, but counselling is an area that should be noted. The Family Law Act implies that counselling will relate to the parties' situations in such a way that many people who go to Family Court counsellors believe they will get counselling to put their marriage back together. That does not happen and most people involved with the act know why it does not happen at that point—it is too late.

Marriage counselling is something that needs to take place much sooner and in the community. We have suggested that that part of the counselling function be removed from the Family Court completely. I do not want people to think that we are abandoning the concept of trying to make marriages work. We believe very strongly in that concept. We are suggesting that counselling take place much more in the community and away from the court, especially at the stage when parties are trying to work out what has gone wrong with their marriage, how to keep it functioning and how to keep a home environment for their children.

The Family Court counselling service should be dealing with the consequences of breakdown and keeping things as civil as possible by letting parties work through their grief over losing their marriage, and so on. Again, you would have to read what we have said. When we were discussing this issue, many of us agreed with Senator Spindler's comment that the bit about reconciliation counselling was probably put in when the bill was being debated in 1974 or 1975 to make the whole thing more palatable, to make it look as though saving marriages was part of the aim.

Saving marriages is my aim in life—so I would not want to be misunderstood on this at all—but it is my experience that by the time people go to a solicitor or to the Family Court their marriage has long since shattered. Although that might not be so for both parties. One party might go to the court and say, `I want my spouse back. I want our problems resolved.' They are the ones who did not realise early that the marriage was in trouble.

We feel it would be better if the legislation dealt with marriage counselling before marriage. Counselling when the marriage is in difficulties should be dealt with separately and greater emphasis placed on it. While the court will continue to deal with the consequences of breakdown, even that should be dealt with in the community far more than it has been.

In relation to the judicial structure of the court, we have recommended that there be a two-tiered structure. There were two tiers of judges once; we are not going back to that. We want to strengthen the role of judicial registrars. We were impressed with the work they are doing. We want to extend that and extend their authority. We have recommended that chapter 3 of the constitution be used to enable judicial registrars to have more power and to be able to deal with greater amounts of property. We have advice that that is possible. If that advice is incorrect, things might have to be done differently. But there are other recommendations of significance there. I would have a lot more judicial registrars, with appeals from their work going to the judges.

We have recommended that magistrates be much more involved, especially in country areas. Things would have to be done to enable that but we see it as of benefit to the community for magistrates to be able to do work which they cannot do at present. We recommend that the Attorney-General take steps in that direction. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to briefly address the report of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues, entitled Funding and administration of the Family Court of Australia. Like Senator Reid, my thoughts went back to the beginnings of this committee, to 1991, when Senator Brownhill and I were jointly responsible for establishing the Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act. Little did we know that we were embarking on a five-year journey.

PARA.TAB: The committee's first report was tabled in 1992. I wish to acknowledge the excellent chairmanship and leadership provided by Senator McKiernan to the committee in producing that report. The committee, in a somewhat different structure, secondly inquired into the child support system. Most recently, it has inquired into the funding and administration of the Family Court of Australia.

I join in the expressions of appreciation to the staff of the committee, who have worked diligently and enthusiastically over the years. In particular, I mention Robina Mills, David Wallace, Matthew Mason-Cox and Jane Vincent.

During those three inquiries my overwhelming impression was that this is perhaps the most traumatic area of the law in which one can be involved. The sheer volume of submissions that we received to the first report—more than 6,000 submissions—would indicate how traumatic many people in the community find this particular experience. We should also acknowledge that, when a marriage shatters, it is very difficult for the law to find solutions; it is essentially a human problem. I think we all found out that in this process there are limits to what we as legislators can do and what the law can do in remedying something that is essentially a human tragedy.

This also needs to be borne in mind when we talk about the Family Court and those who work in it. I have found throughout that, without exception, Family Court personnel devote themselves, with great diligence and conscientiousness, to a task which at all times is extremely difficult. I believe that this needs to be borne in mind, especially when reading this report in which the committee has expressed some clear criticisms about the administration and funding procedures of the Family Court. So, firstly, we must bear in mind the immense and difficult task confronted by personnel at the court; and, secondly, we need to take into account the fact that the tasks of the court were not as clearly defined in the legislation as perhaps they could have been.

Senator Reid has referred already to the comment I made during the committee deliberations, that perhaps it was wrong to include—and it may have been a political move—the task of reconciliation in the tasks of the Family Court. This is in no way to understate that task: it is an important one and must be pursued. Obviously, the saving of every marriage is a task that we must pursue, especially if there are children involved. However, by the time people come to the Family Court, in most cases the time for that is past. If the Family Court finds that there is still a glimmer of hope, then it may be more appropriate to refer such reconciliation efforts to agencies who are directly concerned with and focused on that particular effort, rather than to incorporate it into the work of the court.

This, of course, does not include the counselling that takes place as a particular case proceeds within the court's structure. Even in that case, I believe that the main task of the counselling is to find the best possible solution for the two separating partners and, more particularly, for any children involved in the situation—and that must at all times remain the highest priority of the court.

It is useful to note that the committee has stated that, for the current work the court is undertaking, the funding is adequate. I emphasise `the current work' because it is quite clear that there are areas, particularly for people in remote locations, where the court could and should extend its services. In that case, the committee recommends that the Family Court approach the Department of Finance, document clearly the additional services that are demanded by the needs of the community, and base further funding negotiations on a clear understanding of policy decisions to meet those needs.

It will also be useful to have, from time to time, regular external reviews of the court and an efficiency audit by the Auditor-General as a guide that would assist the administrators in the Family Court. I believe that some of the other recommendations will no doubt be dealt with in some detail by people in the profession and people in the court system, such as the role of judicial registrars that the committee recommends, and also the suggestion that other courts, particularly magistrates and local courts, enter the field more extensively with the support of the Family Court.

A separate word needs to be said for the area of mediation, which the committee in principle certainly supports, as have previous committee reports. This is clearly an area which will expand greatly in the future and may save many a court case from proceeding. However, it should be noted that the mediation field is still in its infancy. When we discussed amendments to the Family Law Act in this chamber recently, it became a matter of debate whether private mediators are adequately accredited and whether there is sufficient supervision of the work that they would carry out.

The minister then referred the Senate to a discussion paper that addressed possible regulations that would be drawn up by the government. But on perusing that discussion paper, I have found that there is no real provision for the qualifications or accreditation of private mediators. That, therefore, remains a deficiency. Certainly in the transitionary period, until that is properly established and proper supervision is provided, the continued involvement of the Family Court would, in my personal view, be useful.

The committee has also made several recommendations about the responsibility for the management and administration of the Family Court. It has suggested that a more collegiate body would make it a more appropriate style of administration. That would probably be welcomed by both the Chief Justice of the Family Court and the Chief Executive Officer.
I commend this report to the Senate. I believe that it is yet another worthwhile step in the reforms to the area of family law which this parliament must undertake.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise very briefly to say a few words on this report of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues. I will restrain and restrict myself because obviously I have not read the report. Therefore, I am not in a position to comment on the content of it or the recommendations contained therein. I would hope that others outside of this place would also restrict themselves in the same way and that they would not just jump into an immediate defensive mode, putting their hands out to get more and more money for the Family Court of Australia or, indeed—perhaps to pick up a point that Senator Reid made earlier—to ask for another Bankcard, Mastercard or Visa card to continue living in debt.

PARA.TAB: I acknowledge in my brief contribution to the report the kind words that Senator Reid, the deputy chair of the committee, had to say about my performance as chair of the previous joint select committee in the previous parliament—words which were enjoined by Senator Spindler. It is by reason of my previously held position that I have retained my interest in the content of this particular report.

This body, the Family Court of Australia, impacts on the lives of far too many people. It is a controversial court not only because of the role by its mere establishment it plays, but also because of the prominence some of the personnel included in the court seek to give it. I am not so sure that that is in the best interests of the court or the functioning of law in this country. I hope that the persons involved in the court will restrain themselves from public comment until they read the report, examine its ramifications and conclusions, and then make informed comment. I would also hope that the presentation of this report might represent something of a sea change in the affairs of the Family Court of Australia.

It might, hopefully, now get on with the business of implementing and administering the Family Law Act of Australia rather than engaging itself and its personnel in matters which are not the province of the court and which it is not funded for, and it might concentrate on the job in hand. Without reading the content of the report, I, like my colleagues, commend the report to the parliament. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on Public Works, I present the following report: No 26 of 1995—Development of facilities for the Artillery Centre, Puckapunyal, Victoria. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: The report which I have just tabled concerns a proposal, sponsored by the Department of Defence, for the relocation of the Artillery Centre from North Head in Sydney to Puckapunyal, Victoria.

PARA.TAB: The stated purpose of the proposal is to meet the training requirements of the School of Artillery, to make best use of existing facilities at Puckapunyal. This proposal will provide the school with ready access to a suitable field firing range.

The proposal examined by the committee involves the provision of office accommodation, instructional and storage facilities and living accommodation. The estimated outturn cost of the project is $34.8 million. The committee has recommended that the proposal should proceed.

The relocation of the School of Artillery from North Head has been the subject of a number of studies undertaken by Defence and since 1990 public announcements by a number of Defence ministers have alluded to this.

Originally the school was to go to Townsville. With the relocation of the 1st Armoured Regiment to Darwin, facilities become available at Puckapunyal. This factor, and the large field firing range at Puckapunyal, prompted Defence to re-examine the Townsville option.

A further study revealed that the school could be located at Puckapunyal at significantly less cost than Townsville, or other possible locations for that matter, by constructing a number of new facilities and refurbishing existing facilities.

The proposal examined by the committee was somewhat different from other projects examined during the year. In this particular instance there was intense opposition to the move from North Head from local members of parliament, Manly Council and a number of community groups. The honourable member for Warringah, Mr Tony Abbott, left the committee in no doubt regarding his opposition to the move.

Despite claims to the contrary, the committee believes opposition to the move is based more on local interests than national defence interests. North Head is a very pleasant location, but it lacks access to a field firing range. The range at Holsworthy is no longer suited for the type of training undertaken. It suffers from urban encroachment, is too small and is under the flight path to Sydney airport. It is also a two-hour drive away from North Head.

Training facilities at the school are inadequate. Clearly something needs to be done. The committee has concluded that for the School of Artillery to operate effectively and efficiently, it needs to be located adjacent to a suitable field firing range and to have modern, purpose designed training facilities.

There was some apprehension in the minds of representatives of the local community about the future use of the land at North Head to be vacated by the school. The committee considers that much of the apprehension is focused on the developed area, comprising 15 hectares, occupied by the School of Artillery. It consists of buildings, roads, married quarters and other support infrastructure.

The future of the balance of the land, some 60 hectares, has been assured by the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray). This land is either natural bushland or is on the Register of the National Estate. It will be incorporated into Sydney Harbour National Park.

I can say that they have some of the most breathtaking views you would ever want to see anywhere, looking across Sydney Harbour. It is no wonder that Tony Abbott, the member for Warringah, and Mrs Bishop in the adjoining electorate and other interested local government people are so concerned about the future of North Head itself.

Whilst the future use of the larger area has been predetermined, a management regime will need to be developed under the direction of the Section 22 Committee. The Public Works Committee believes future uses of the 15 hectares should complement the objectives of the management plan for the larger site. The committee also believes this planning context should therefore preclude any development or adaptive reuse of land and buildings which are incompatible with, or detract from, a significant natural recreational asset on the shores of Sydney Harbour.

I should point out that these matters will all be addressed by the Section 22 Committee comprising Commonwealth, state and local government officials, which will develop a management regime for the land at North Head. Both state and federal members of parliament will be members of the Section 22 Committee.

It was also pointed out that an artillery battery needs to be located with the school at Puckapunyal. It was suggested that decisions regarding the relocation of the school should await the outcome of the Army 21 study, which is examining the army's force structure for the next century. The study is due for completion in December.

The rest of my speech concerns Puckapunyal. In deference to my colleague Senator Watson, who I believe wants to make some comments about another matter, I seek leave to have the remainder of the speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: At present there is no battery at Puckapunyal. The Committee has therefore concluded that will be necessary for an artillery battery to be located at Puckapunyal to support the School. Whilst this must await the outcome of the Army 21 study, based on the evidence from Defence there is every confidence to believe that a battery will be relocated to Puckapunyal.
Honourable members may be aware that in recent years Puckapunyal has been upgraded to a modern and very pleasant Army base—in fact one of the largest Army bases.
The Public Works Committee has taken a keen interest in developments there.
Some of the works examined in recent years include
Construction of a Royal Australian Army Service Corps Centre—estimated cost—8.4 million dollars in 1972
Armoured Centre redevelopment—estimated cost 12 million dollars in 1981
And more recently, in 1990
Stage 1 redevelopment—estimated cost—44 million dollars.
The Committee was pleased with the positive response from the local shire to the proposal.

In terms of the scope of the proposed work, which comprises new construction and refurbishment, the Committee has concluded that the scope of proposed refurbishment makes good use of existing facilities. New construction has been restricted to the provision of specialised training facilities and three new accommodation blocks to be shared between officers and senior non-commissioned officers, depending on demand. The siting of elements of new construction is in accordance with the master plan.
I should mention that the scope and the cost of the proposed work includes the facilities required by an artillery battery.
The estimated outturn cost of the project is $34.8 million.

The Committee questioned Defence about the basis of costings for the Seymour area when compared with capital city costs. Defence advised the Committee that prices will be competitive and this and variations between capital city and local costings were factored into the cost estimate.

Some concern was raised about the availability of housing for families associated with the Artillery Centre and the artillery battery. The Committee was assured by the Defence Housing Authority that there is a stock of good quality houses available. Upgrading and refurbishment of poorer quality houses is programmed to occur before the arrival of the School of Artillery.
I commend the report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the 17th report of the Select Committee on Superannuation entitled Super and Broken Work Patterns, together with submissions and the Hansard transcript of evidence.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate and move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: The 17th report of the Select Committee on Superannuation examines the adequacy of retirement incomes policy arrangements in meeting the needs of those members of the community whose participation in the paid work force falls outside the traditional 30 to 40 years of continuous involvement. The inquiry has predominantly focused on women, as, in the main, they are the members of the community who are most affected. This does not negate the fact that some men also experience broken work patterns.

PARA.TAB: Changes to superannuation legislation over recent years have significantly increased membership of superannuation schemes, most significantly for women. However, a recent study by the Retirement Income Modelling Task Force of the distribution of private sector superannuation assets and contributions found that women had substantially lower average superannuation asset accumulations than men.

Throughout the course of the inquiry it was obvious that the current superannuation system is designed for the individual with a traditional employment history, the individual who enters the paid labour force full time at the end of their education and stays there until retirement. This pattern fits most men. It is not the pattern that fits most women. It does not fit women because: women have a higher incidence of part-time work; women's broken work force participation patterns mean that they have fewer years of contributory service; and women's average earnings are lower than men's.

It is therefore appropriate to ask whether the superannuation scheme as it is currently structured adequately meets the needs of women, and by implication all those with broken work patterns. The simple answer is no!

The committee, however, was very conscious that broader community expectations abound that influence women's participation in the paid work force and that the achievement of total equality in retirement income would require changes to other aspects of society. Superannuation should not and must not be beholden to overcome the inequalities that exist elsewhere, but all efforts must be taken to ensure that the system we have in place does not unnecessarily compound them.

Of particular concern to the committee is that the shift towards self-funded retirement may result in a two-tier society. The fear is that those who, for whatever reason, are not able to provide for their retirement—a significant proportion of whom will be women—and therefore remain on the age pension will become `second class citizens', scorned by society. It must be acknowledged that for some women, who forgo years in the paid work force to undertake caring and family responsibilities, occupationally linked superannuation will never be sufficient to provide for them in their retirement.

Measures to reduce tax imbalance: the committee considered that some aspects of the current contribution system could be improved to assist workers with intermittent work patterns. The committee was concerned that the limited tax advantage flowing to low income earners from superannuation contributions did not encourage such contributions. The committee therefore recommends that measures which would redress the tax imbalance for low income earners be investigated.

Transfer protocols, vesting and portability: the committee recognised that intermittent worker work patterns can result in a worker having a number of disparate accounts and, because of the employment periods required for vesting, the worker missing out on any employer contributions above the mandated superannuation guarantee charge, SGC. The issue of small amounts has been addressed by the committee previously but it believes that there are further opportunities for improvement. The committee makes three recommendations to improve the position of such workers.

The first is that the government ensure that appropriate transfer protocols are adopted by all funds accepting compulsory contributions. Those who have read the committee's report on the superannuation guarantee charge will know that this is not a new recommendation. The second is that the exemptions relating to vesting, portability and preservation, together with all other exemptions relating to superannuation in the Sex Discrimination Act 1984, be removed before the end of March 1997. The third is that the superannuation legislation be amended to require immediate vesting of all employer contributions.

Over 65 contributions: some who work intermittently may wish to continue to work beyond the retirement age and currently are disadvantaged in that they cannot contribute to superannuation. The committee recommends that this situation be altered and that the SIS regulations be amended to allow regulated superannuation funds to accept contributions from persons over 65.

Discrimination: the committee took a great deal of evidence on the issue of whether, directly or indirectly, superannuation discriminated against women. The committee concluded that the superannuation system, in most cases, was reflecting inequities prevalent in society more generally and that it was inappropriate to resolve these issues through the superannuation system.

However, two areas remain of concern. One is the differing costs of annuities for men and women. Whilst a range of factors are taken into account in the pricing of some insurance policies—for example, smoking habits for health insurance—only gender is taken into account in the pricing of annuities. The committee is concerned that this is inappropriate and recommends that the government encourage and monitor research on the use of gender and morbidity actuarial tables in respect of the provision of annuities with a view to either amending the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 to exclude the exemption for actuarial or statistical data, or declaring the gender based actuarial tables to be not covered by the exemption if it is discovered that reliance on these tables cannot reasonably justify the resulting discrimination.

The other area of concern to the committee is the difference between the payment of superannuation assets upon death of single persons and those in relationships other than married or de facto compared to those who are in marriage or de facto relationships. The committee recommends that the superannuation regulations be amended so that those in bona fide domestic relationships and single people are treated in the same manner as married and de facto superannuants.

Divorce: an area of significant concern to the community is the treatment of superannuation assets on divorce. The high incidence of divorce and the increasing value of superannuation as an asset within the family unit require that clear guidelines be determined. The committee understands that a working group has been in existence for some time, with little or no obvious results being evident. The committee is greatly concerned about the serious delay that has occurred in the resolution of this problem and recommends in the strongest terms that this issue be rectified as a priority.

Education: the committee is concerned that the current superannuation awareness raising campaign,`Super: it grows on you' will have little impact on the many women who are yet to recognise the need to engage in any form of financial planning. Anecdotal evidence suggests that in some, maybe many, instances, women are anticipating that their partners will look after them in retirement. Therefore, the committee recommends that, firstly, the Office of the Status of Women develop a comprehensive educational strategy to raise understanding and awareness amongst women of the components of, and the imperative to engage in, financial planning; secondly, the government, in conjunction with the superannuation industry, should develop an educational strategy to promote understanding and awareness of superannuation which goes beyond the provision of information only and which involves active participation of the community.

In particular, the strategy should address the needs of women, both in terms of the type of information they receive and the mechanisms by which this information is delivered. Simultaneously with the development of the strategy, the committee recommends that the effectiveness of the `Super: it grows on you' campaign be closely monitored, especially in relation to its impact on women.

Female trustees: men will gain a greater interest in superannuation if it addresses their employment patterns and recognises their broader needs and aspirations. This will best be achieved by involving women in the management of the funds, in particular as trustees. The committee therefore recommends that strategies be developed which provide avenues through which women can gain the necessary confidence and expertise to participate as trustees. Such a move will also have significant benefits for the superannuation industry, ensuring that it more fully reflects the community it serves and drawing on the widest pool of talent available to it.

To ensure that this occurs, the committee has made three recommendations: firstly, that the Affirmative Action Agency develop reporting requirements for superannuation funds of programs that will enhance equal opportunities for women to act as fund trustees. It is recommended that these reporting requirements be ready for implementation by the 1996-97 financial year; secondly, that regulated, non-excluded superannuation funds be required to comply with current affirmative action program development and annual reporting in relation to developing equal opportunities for women to act as fund trustees in order to maintain their complying status; and, thirdly, that the appointment of female alternates be a matter upon which superannuation funds must report to the Affirmative Action Agency and the Insurance and Superannuation Commission.

Pension age increase: an area of dissent within the committee was the raising of the pension age for women from 60 to 65 years of age. The implementation of the change, to be phased in over a 20-year period, has already commenced. The major parties have committed themselves to the increase whilst the Democrats strongly oppose it. However, all committee members strongly support the recommendation that the government undertake an information program specifically targeted at those women who are likely to be affected by the change in the pension age in the coming years, which explains the change and outlines the alternative maintenance benefits available. This should be supported by an identified officer within the Department of Social Security from whom women concerned about the change can seek advice.

Meeting the challenge: during the inquiry it has become clear that the past and present experience of women, and their capacity to provide for their retirement, is such that it would be irresponsible for any government to ignore the arguments for change and allow the status quo to continue. It has also become clear that removing the obstacles inherent in the superannuation system which mitigate against many women achieving a retirement income that will ensure a dignified standard of living will benefit all members of society, both male and female.

The committee is aware that many solutions will be found in areas outside the scope of this inquiry. However, the challenge remains to ensure that the superannuation system that Australia carries into the 21st century is the most equitable system possible so that in future years it will be judged resoundingly as a significant contribution towards ensuring equality and dignity for all members of the community. I commend this report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make a few comments on this report which, I believe, in line with the other reports we have made, is of the same high quality. That is due in very large part to the quality of the staff and to the quality of the committee members, I presume.
—Pity the other select committees aren't of the same quality.
—This is true. Let me underline not only the quality of the committee members but also the quality of the chairperson. I have said that before. I want to say it again.

PARA.TAB: I want to make only two points in this debate. The first is that it is obvious that the current superannuation system is designed substantially for full-time workers with unbroken career paths; that is, people who begin work in their teens, continue with full-time work throughout their working life and retire in their late fifties or sixties; that is, still mainly men.

I was struck by what one witness said. The plea went along these lines: why can't you admit that the present superannuation system is not designed to meet women's needs? I do not know that that is an entirely accurate description of the system, but it certainly gave the committee cause to think.

The other comment I want to make deals with a particular concern of the Australian Democrats about increasing the pension age of women to 65. Chapter 15 of the report, which is titled `Moving the goal posts—increasing the pension age for women', I believe, underlines the various sides in this debate. I believe this chapter underlines and reinforces the position taken by the Democrats in this debate, and that is that the pension age should not be increased. I believe the evidence given by witnesses underlines the position we have taken.

TALK.START.PARA: —I bet they did.

—Of course they did. If there is a question of equality to be resolved, and the conclusion to the chapter points out that this is the Democrats' position—and I believe the witnesses supported our contention—the pension age for women should not be raised to 65. If it is a question of equality, the pension age for men should be lowered. I say this for a number of reasons. I believe they were brought out in this chapter.
—What would it cost?
—That is a good question. That was never argued strongly by the government when the pension age was raised. They argued about a lot of other things.

PARA.TAB: The participation of women in the labour force over recent decades has improved. There is no doubt about that. That is not reflected in figures for women aged 60 and over. It is not reflected in figures for women in their fifties either. I draw attention particularly to paragraphs 14.34 and 14.26 that underline this.

The increase in women's superannuation coverage also does not mean that a majority of women will have adequate cover to retire with dignity even in 20 years time. It may be that younger women now in their teens or early twenties will be able to retire with an adequate superannuation cover, but this will depend on a number of factors. It will depend on a number of current barriers being overcome. These barriers include still lower rates of pay, broken work history due to caring and child-bearing roles and the much lower participation rate of older women in the paid work force.

The Department of Social Security argued before the committee that raising the pension age sent a clear message to employers and the community at large that the government did not endorse early retirement for men and women. I believe that argument is a little self-serving. There have been attempts by employers to force women to retire at 60. They have been strenuously resisted by women. A number of test cases have established the right of women to remain in the paid work force beyond 60. That is the element which has caused the change in the attitude of employers.

The Department of Social Security also stated before the committee that a range of alternative income support payments exist to assist women affected by the increase in women's qualifying age for the age pension. Again, this is a little misleading. The Department of Social Security did not say that the alternatives provided by the department are at a lower rate than the age pension, lead to stigmatisation, and attract significant disadvantages such as the activity test and case management for jobsearch and newstart allowances. I have put on the record what women say about what happened to them because of those provisions. If it is necessary to provide an alternative income support system I believe that is proof that claims about equality and labour market participation are wrong.
Let me read, therefore, the conclusion of this chapter:

The Committee notes that the two major parties have committed themselves to the increase. The Democrats remain of the view that the pension age for women should not be increased and that any inequality should be addressed by lowering the pension age for men.

SPEECH.PARA: I heartily commend the report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know there are only a few minutes left, but I want to raise a couple of matters in relation to this report—another very important report—which covers a range of issues. I want to pay special tribute to Krista and the others in the secretariat.

There are widely differing views amongst the members of this committee, particularly in some areas, and one of those that Senator Watson did not mention was the chapter on `Choice of fund'. I think it reflects the goodwill of members of the committee that we were able, at the conclusion of the final paragraph of the chapter on `Choice of fund', to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Members of the Committee hold strongly different views on the issue of employee choice of fund. These reflect the different philosophies of the political parties.

I think it is fair to say that we do have different philosophies with regard to the choice of fund. But if we are going to look at freedom of choice in the context of trying to help solve the small amounts problem, we need to think not only of employees, and employees who are involved sometimes in quite large industry funds, but also of people who in some cases are providing for their own retirement by way of self-employed funds, people who these days by choice are doing some other work—whether it be perhaps doing a month's lecturing at a TAFE college or spending a small amount of time in a hospital as a resident medical officer.

PARA.TAB: This impacts on their own personal superannuation. Choice of funds does allow people in these circumstances to make sure that all of their preparation for retirement and all of their funding for their retirement is going into the one fund. This lessens the impacts of any fees and charges that might be levied, and it certainly does not allow any of these amounts to erode.

So there were a lot of differing opinions amongst the members of the committee with regard to freedom of choice of funds. I hold my own particular strong views because I believe there should be freedom of choice. A person may choose at the start of his working life to use a certain fund. No matter where that fund is, should he change jobs or should he have a variety of jobs, I believe he should have the choice to be able to keep that fund for the remainder of his working life. Currently that is not the case in many situations. That is just one of the issues that was dealt with at length.

Also, the issue of taxation was touched on by Senator Watson. I think it is very important that we see that people who are on low incomes because of the taxation arrangement of superannuation contributions are not disadvantaged by the scheme that has been put in place, because they pay an unfair tax burden on their contributions when compared with those people who are in a far better situation.

They are two issues that were very important and were discussed at length. I am pleased to commend this report to senators because I believe it has a wealth of information which can be of great value.
