TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder whether we can have the tolerance of the chamber. I believe we only need a few minutes more for the final printing of the amendments proposed by the government. I wonder whether we could move to consider the requests under schedule 1 and 16. Then I am advised we should be ready to proceed with the amendments. Is that acceptable?
—The requests moved by Senator Knowles are presently before the chair. The question is that the House of Representatives be requested to make the amendments.

—The requested amendments that we are asking the House of Representatives to make relate to Meridian Investment. The request provides that those investments are deemed to be saved investments. As I explained last night in the second reading stage of this bill, the trust collapsed in 1990 and investors lost a considerable amount of money at that time. The trust has now, of course, been relisted as the Meridian Investment Trust. Since that time, investments have increased considerably. However, the gains have not been sufficient to make up for the massive losses that originally occurred.

PARA.TAB: Investments in the original trust were exempt from the unrealised capital gains rules as they were classified as saved investments. When the trust was relisted they were no longer exempt and the total gain since that time has been assessed under the income test. This has caused large reductions in many investors' pensions. The coalition indicated last week that it would be proposing requests in the committee stage of this bill to treat Meridian investments as saved investments until July 1996.

We heard today that the government intends to give people an ex gratia payment but that is not going to put them back into the position they would have been in if these were saved investments. I have moved the requests that the House of Representatives make that amendment for that reason.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government is not minded to accept these requests. The government recently decided to bring forward the well-received extended deeming measures to clients holding Meridian Investment Trust investments in recognition of the high rates of return being assessed for this investment, despite the large capital losses of investors. Global Funds Management, the managers of MIT, had asked the government to bring this forward.

PARA.TAB: The government believes it has introduced the fairest arrangement for holders of MITs. Clients with units purchased before the government decision have now had their payments reassessed using the extended deeming rules. Arrears have been paid from the first pay day on or after 24 October 1995.

The opposition is suggesting a total retrospective exemption from as early as 1988 from the income test for MIT unit holders until extended deeming is introduced in 1996. This would be completely impossible to administer and completely unnecessary. The government feels it has fixed this problem and it is not necessary to make this request for an amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition will not be opposing the Student and Youth Assistance Amendment (Youth Training Allowance) Bill (No. 2) and the Student and Youth Assistance Amendment (Youth Training Allowance) Bill (No. 3), but I propose moving an amendment during my second reading contribution. PARA.TAB: The purpose of these two bills is to make changes to the youth training allowance provisions which were incorporated in 1994 in part 8 of the Student and Youth Assistance Act 1973. The provisions of that part are modelled on the jobsearch allowance provisions contained in the Social Security Act 1991. Any changes to the jobsearch allowance provisions need to be mirrored in the youth training allowance provisions.

The effect of these bills are to mirror amendments proposed to the Social Security Act 1991 by the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Carer Pension and Other Measures) Bill 1995 and the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill 1995 to ensure consistency in income support arrangements. I will deal firstly with the Student and Youth Assistance Amendment (Youth Training Allowance) Bill (No. 2) 1995.

Schedule 1 makes amendments relating to compensation recovery which affect the calculation of youth training allowance entitlement for those who receive a periodic lump sum payment to which they are entitled under any state or territory law. In addition, they operate to adjust the youth training allowance entitlement of people who have partners who receive or are entitled to receive various pensions payable under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986.

Under schedule 2 of this bill, 15-year-olds who fall within the youth training allowance definition of independent are to be paid youth training allowance rather than special benefit even if they do not meet the work force requirements of youth training allowance. Fifteen-year-olds who live with parents in receipt of Commonwealth income support and have a work force history will also qualify for youth training allowance. Youth training allowance overpayments may be offset against any student assistance payments, such as Austudy, which that person may subsequently be entitled to receive under schedule 3 of this bill.

Schedule 4 mirrors the transferability of waiting period provisions in schedule 17 of the carer bill and allows waiting periods to be transferable across payment types, including youth training allowance, where a client changes benefits during the waiting period. Schedule 5 of the bill proposes changes to waiver and recovery of debt provisions. In certain circumstances, part or all of a debt may be waived. Debts over $50 can be recovered by withholding youth training allowance payments. There is also provision for negotiated settlements, part payment of debt and non-recovery in circumstances where recovery would be inequitable.

Schedule 6 deals with provisions relating to bank accounts into which youth training allowance is to be paid. The rent assistance threshold for youth training allowance clients is increased by $5 under schedule 7, and there are further minor amendments under schedule 8.

Turning to the Student and Youth Assistance Amendment (Youth Training Allowance) Bill (No. 3): schedule 1 of this bill contains amendments to the way in which deeming rules apply to investments held by recipients of the youth training allowance. Schedule 2 eliminates the need for recipients of the youth training allowance to transfer to sickness allowance if their period of sickness is more than 13 weeks.

Schedule 3 will allow a person to access earnings credits notwithstanding that the person's ordinary income amount would, if the income test were applied, reduce the rate of assistance to nil. The earnings credit scheme operates to provide an incentive for a person to undertake part-time or casual employment. Schedule 4 removes redundant references to jobsearch allowance from the Student and Youth Assistance Act 1973. As I have indicated, the coalition will not be opposing these bills. However, I move:
At the end of the motion, add:

SPEECH.PARA: ", but the Senate condemns the failure of the Government's measures to assist young unemployed people".

PARA.TAB: We have just seen the third consecutive rise in the unemployment figures. Unemployment now stands at 8.7 per cent and 787,000 people are out of work in Australia. This number does not include the 106,000 discouraged job seekers who miss out because they are not actively looking for work because they do not expect to find any. It does not include the 177,300 parents who want work and are otherwise available, except that they cannot get appropriate child care. It does not include the 82,200 unemployed people who are sick or otherwise prevented from actively looking for work in the survey week. It does not include the 140,000 people who want work and are available but are in TAFE, or university or training and were not actively looking for work at the time of the Australian Bureau of Statistics' survey.

There are approximately 85,000 people in subsidised employment at any one time under government programs such as jobstart, new work opportunities and so on—perhaps half of whom will be back on the unemployment queues when the subsidy runs out. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take not of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I welcome the opportunity to take note of the annual report for 1994-95 of the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation. In 1994-95, AWRAP was integrated with the International Wool Secretariat to form a customer oriented international marketing and research organisation. Its goal was and is to build a sustainable demand for Australian wool by ensuring that wool and wool products satisfy our customers.

PARA.TAB: With trade barriers collapsing and an increasingly fierce level of competition in the textile industry, it is imperative to have a strong organisation focused on looking after the interests of wool promotion and wool growers. After the turbulence the wool industry has experienced in the past few years, it is stability and commitment to succeed that we need.

In reviewing the activities of the now merged organisations for 1994-95, there are many notable achievements. AWRAP's research and development was more closely aligned with customer needs, while the IWS launched a $70 million international Woolmark advertising campaign in Australia and for the first time more than 3,000 firms paid a Woolmark licence fee. An annual fee is now paid by spinners, weavers and garment manufacturers wishing to use the IWS's certification marks, Woolmark and Woolblendmark, on their products. These trade and identification marks rate with such notable product identifications as the three-pointed star for Mercedes and the golden arches for McDonald's.

As the report notes, this is a clear indication that the Woolmark is the most widely recognised apparel symbol in the world. Chairman Mac Drysdale goes on to note that the acceptance of the licence fee has brought added commercial discipline to the organisation to perform in a way that benefits both licensees and growers. It was unfortunate that New Zealand did not see fit to remain a funding partner of the International Wool Secretariat, and that decision may cost our Tasman neighbours dearly.

The Australian Wool Realisation and Promotion Organisation is the body that has the responsibility to receive and spend the compulsory industry levy, which is 8 1/2 per cent, of which 4 1/2 per cent goes to the disposal of the stockpile as administered by Wool International. The remaining four per cent goes to AWRAP, and 3 1/2 per cent of that is spent on promotion and one-half of one per cent is spent on research and development.

There are two ways to sell more wool. One, of course, is to have substantially reduced prices, which over the last five years has not worked very well. The second is to promote the product, and to promote the product you have to both market it in the sense that you promote it with advertising funds, but you have also got to have forward selling methods that spread the risk so that growers alone are not bearing all of the risk.

With the actual promotion of the product—and that is what AWRAP is involved in through its compulsory industry levy—when the price fell the amount that was recovered by AWRAP to be used for promotion fell, and it has been very pleasing to see the price rise in 1994-95. Of course, it has slipped a little now, but that made it possible for a larger contribution to be made in the form of the advertising campaign which is quite evident now. The promotion and research component is very important too and vital to be maintained.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Wool International was born from the former Australian Wool Realisation Commission in December 1993. As a statutory authority, Wool International is committed to disposing of the stockpile, enhancing the long-term viability of the wool industry, and repaying the government-guaranteed debt. The act under which Wool International was established confers on the organisation a responsibility to encourage forward selling mechanisms for risk management, amongst other things.

PARA.TAB: To prosper and indeed survive, the industry must hasten its introduction of risk management techniques for both wool growers and buyers. The market must move away from its near total reliance on the auction system. After 150 years of wool being grown in this country, we still have about 85 per cent of growers accepting a spot price—in other words, they put their whole 12 months of production up on the day and take it—which, of course, is subject to enormous variations in price.

It is in the interests of both growers and buyers to have a more sophisticated risk management system. Although forward contracts or forward trading frightens growers because it is something they do not understand, it is essential for the future of the industry. The auction system will remain, but there must be more choice.

The Garnaut proposals overall have worked extremely well in reducing the stockpile and also reducing the debt. I believe that, regardless of the role of Wool International and the stockpile in recent months, there would still have been a correction in prices because China has not been active in the market. The crucial missing factor is market confidence. Once that is restored, textile activity will lift and prices will begin to rise again, led initially by fine wool, which will be most affected by the reduced availability in 1996 if the drought continues to break.

I wish Wool International the best as it readies itself for privatisation, which will occur after 1 July 1997. The options for a privatised Wool International would have to provide choice to growers. Until these recent price falls, the future role of Wool International had really risen to unrealistic levels in the industry because it had been so successful. I think we must put it in perspective; it will be two years before Wool International is out of debt—in other words, in 1997-98.

Presently there are 2.9 million bales in the stockpile and a debt resting on that of $1.6 billion. At the continued sale of 185,000 bales a quarter at the end of selling season 1997-98, there should be an approximate net worth of $1.4 billion which will be returned to growers, in whole or in part. In a new privatised body, perhaps in the form of a public company, the two requirements are that it must be able to provide a service to growers and it must be able to charge for those services—in other words, make a profit.

Basically, any privatisation at the end of 1997-98 must focus on shareholder value and must provide a choice to growers, and there must be alternatives provided to the possibility of 100 per cent liquidation of the stockpile.

Wool International will be judged by the new role recently announced last week or the week before by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Bob Collins). Wool International Holdings will source buyers overseas, give depth to the futures market, which is at present underutilised and undercapitalised, and will provide a new choice to growers. We need a way of removing the risk that is presently solely held by growers and the new futures contract and selling proposal under the auspices of Wool International will provide a motivation for this.

I briefly say in connection with Wool International that the new board is about to be announced. I look forward to this board having some substantial grower representation because it is very important to have that grower input. I wish the new board all the success when it is announced.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the remarks of my colleague Senator Sandy Macdonald. I will make some similar observations and some additional ones.

PARA.TAB: To a point Wool International has done a remarkably good job in getting the stockpile down to now under 3 million bales and the debt down to somewhere in the order of $1.5 billion. But I believe that their policy of forward selling and what appears to have been a downward pressure on the market in the last three or four months have not necessarily been in the best interests of woolgrowers. I think that they should have shown more flexibility in the way that they managed the sale of the stockpile.

I believe that there was a case for limiting that forward selling and getting it back into the current quarter to take some of the pressure off the depressed prices that occurred. I think that is the one blight on their performance to this time. I would certainly hope that, between now and the start of the autumn selling season and going into next year, the board of management will take into consideration the points I have raised that woolgrowers and industry representatives have raised with me. I believe, from the support that is being shown by senators at this time, that they support us as well.

I think the minister should take a firm stance. In saying that, I am not being critical at this stage of him. Having said all that, I think it is important that, in the development of their privatisation program, they do in fact in the first instance give growers the opportunity to take up the option of getting their money back.

—I will join with you in calling for a full judicial inquiry into the events surrounding the death of the late Penny Easton. We have not got that, Senator Campbell; neither you nor I have got that. I called for it. You were going to support it; you have been silent. What we need now is either a judicial inquiry or a royal commission into the affairs of what is known as Wanneroo Inc. I do not have a better name for it.

PARA.TAB: There has been an inquiry set up by the West Australian government. It is known as the Kyle inquiry because its chair is an eminent citizen, one Mr Peter Kyle. It has commenced taking evidence. The first witness to the Kyle inquiry into Wanneroo Inc. has been none other than the former mayor of Wanneroo, the person recently convicted of official corruption, who is now serving a prison sentence for that crime. He has been the first witness. He has provided to the people of Western Australia—indeed, to the people of Australia because it is now an event of national importance—categorical evidence of why there ought to be a royal commission into the affairs of Wanneroo Inc.

The reason I say that is for what has not been published. Mr Kyle, in order to protect individuals who may be implicated in Wanneroo Inc., has had to order that the names and certain events not be published. The reason for that is that the inquiry is being held under very limited terms of reference. This is not something new or unique to Western Australia, but this particular inquiry has very limited terms of reference. It is being held under the Local Government Act of Western Australia. The inquiry allows no protection whatsoever and no privilege to any person who wants to come forward and give evidence about the corruption that occurred within the city boundaries of Wanneroo over quite a period of time.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are not likely to come.

—They are not likely to come, and that is the unfortunate part about it. The really unfortunate part about that is that, as I said in opening, a lot of innocent people who have faithfully served the people of Wanneroo, and indeed the people of Western Australia, at great personal cost to themselves on the council of Wanneroo are all being smeared because there have been some corrupt individuals who served on the council. Of course, we may not be able to get to the bottom of this unless there is some protection and privilege given to the people who do want to go forward and give evidence to the inquiry and, hopefully, that would cleanse the council and lead to further convictions.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting that a state such as Western Australia is hiding and running away from such an inquiry. What have they got to hide? There must be something to hide if such an inquiry is not going to be held. That question was answered this afternoon in the other place, when the local member for Moore, Mr Paul Filing, stood up in the House of Representatives and made a speech and named quite a large number of people who are, and continue to be, involved in the corruption that has gone on, and perhaps is still going on, within the boundaries of the city of Wanneroo. I am not going to refer to all of the names here tonight. I do refer and commend people to the speech of the local member of parliament, Mr Paul Filing, and I ask them to read it with great care.

With Mr Filing's speech and with other matters that have occurred within the Kyle inquiry, I think the pressure is upon the Premier of Western Australia, indeed the government of Western Australia, to broaden the terms of reference to provide for a royal commission to get to the bottom of the corruption that has occurred in the city of Wanneroo, and it is going to reach a position where the government will not be able to afford it. Mr Court may have a lot of very important people that he seeks to protect on the way through. Some of the people may serve in his own parliament; some of the people who were named in the House of Representatives today are actually currently members of the Western Australian parliament, and I am not just talking about one or two people, there are more than that.

I fear that, unless the terms of reference are broadened, we will not get to the bottom of it without a royal commission, but I think that one is certainly coming. The weight of public opinion is such that the government, in order to save itself in the finish, will just have to bow to the will of the people; will have to open up the inquiry; and will, in turn, expose those people, including some very senior people in the Western Australian government, to the possible charges that will, I believe, inevitably arise from the report of such a royal commission.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was part of the Senate select committee which examined unresolved whistleblower cases. This all-party committee delivered a unanimous report, and many of the senators involved have addressed the Senate expressing their further concerns. Unfortunately, the matters we have raised have fallen largely upon deaf ears, particularly within the state of Queensland, which I represent. As a committee, we have raised serious matters of public concern which go to the very heart of the administration of justice. These matters are not limited to Queensland and ought to be of national concern, although it has been appalling to witness the enormous number of complaints which have emanated from Queensland itself.

PARA.TAB: Sadly, our committee was unable to address the majority of complaints due to the limitation of resources, time and limitations as to our jurisdiction. Although the committee was unable to examine the vast majority of submissions from these people, I have read many of them and met personally with some to hear their cases in more detail. It is evident that many people in Australia have legitimate complaints which are not being listened to nor being addressed. Politicians and bureaucracies unfortunately have frustrated and even whitewashed some of these complaints. Ultimately, the responsibility for these actions must rest with the state ministers who have been alerted to these wrongdoings.

In one case examined in detail by our committee, two former police officers, Reynolds and Harris, had their careers ruined because they tried to act on evidence they had which indicated serious misconduct within the senior ranks of the police service. Reynolds and Harris acted in accordance with the guidelines set out in the Fitzgerald report, but unfortunately the police service, the Criminal Justice Commission, the Director of Prosecutions and the Attorney-General all failed to ensure that these two officers were not penalised for doing their duty. Lip service has been given, but justice has not.

In any democracy, the fair and impartial administration of justice is a fundamental postulate. This is not an academic argument—society demands it. There must be openness and accountability—all of which in these issues is lacking in Queensland. This has been exemplified by the dismantling of the Freedom of Information Act through a number of subsequent amendments.

On 4 November 1995, the Courier-Mail reported Premier Wayne Goss's response to our committee's report to the Senate. He accused senators of `misusing their power by holding Senate inquiries for political reasons'. He cited the handling of unresolved whistleblower cases as an example.

TALK.START.PARA: —He just wanted to sweep it under the carpet.

—Exactly. Such a statement is clearly disingenuous. Indeed, in the case of whistleblowers Reynolds and Harris, correspondence proves that the premier, the then Attorney-General, Dean Wells, and the police minister, Terry Mackenroth, were all aware of the serious allegations against former Detective Superintendent Huey. This was many months before Reynolds and Harris received the complaint against Huey upon which they acted.

PARA.TAB: Former police minister Mackenroth, after having read a 30-page memorandum of advice prepared by the Director of Prosecutions and dated 27 August 1990, caused Huey to be removed from the police service. Unfortunately, this occurred in a way which benefited Huey and damaged the whistleblowers. The other ministers, the CJC and the police service have hidden behind the director's advice. Our committee read this advice and has unanimously recommended its public release.

This recommendation was not made lightly, but when all competing interests were weighed, justice demanded its release. The public release of this advice is necessary not only for what it contains but also for what it failed to address. I believe if this matter were properly investigated, as Reynolds and Harris sought, the advice would have come to a different conclusion. These matters have been well addressed in the supplementary submission to the committee by Robert Butler, dated 25 May 1995.

Instead of adopting the course recommended by our committee, the advice has been selectively released and misleadingly used in the prosecution of Harris. This prosecution amounted to an abuse of process in order to silence an effective critic, a public minded whistleblower. Relevant evidence supporting Harris's case was withheld from the courts during his prosecution. This was to his detriment. Such inexcusable and indefensible conduct is a matter of the gravest concern.

Rather than addressing these issues, the premier has whitewashed these matters by accusing the Senate of holding inquiries for political purposes. When making his accusation, the premier failed to recognise that the committee was chaired by a Labor senator and that all five parties of the Senate participated in this seven-member committee. The premier appears still to be shooting the messenger—namely, the Senate committee—rather than dealing with the real issues involved. In fact when Senator Murphy, as chairman, tabled our committee findings, he had this to say:

In the matter of Gordon Harris and John Reynolds, it is clear to me that the actions taken against Mr Harris and Mr Reynolds demonstrated a classic whistleblower dilemma whereby the whistleblower, rather than the disclosures, becomes the focus of attention. The investigations, court cases and appeals to which Mr Harris and Mr Reynolds have been subjected boiled down to Mr Harris being found guilty of disclosing information contrary to the Police Administration Act—an offence determined by a magistrate to be so trivial, and with such mitigating circumstances, that Mr Harris was discharged without having a conviction recorded. It was the committee's view that the severity of the reprisals to which Gordon Harris and John Reynolds were subjected could not be justified and I believe the state should consider some form of compensation for these two people.

SPEECH.PARA: All members of the committee were in agreement with this statement. Justice and honesty demanded this finding. Although a member of the Australian Democrats, I was one of many Queenslanders who worked hard to ensure a Labor victory in 1989. I believed that change was essential to ensure that real reform could be achieved. To suggest that I am disappointed is an understatement.

PARA.TAB: I also supported as a pivotal reform the establishment of the Criminal Justice Commission, which held out real hope to Queenslanders. Unfortunately, it also has thus far failed to live up to our expectations. Our committee was appalled by the ferocity of the CJC's attack upon whistleblowers. The CJC appeared incapable of admitting or even acknowledging a wrong. Rather than adopting such a position, even when blatantly obvious, the CJC went to extraordinary lengths to discredit whistleblowers. The CJC attempted to mislead the committee, I believe, and used its considerable resources in this endeavour.

It is hoped that under a new chairman these matters will be addressed. It is further hoped that he will personally examine submissions now made public from this inquiry. Likewise it is necessary for the media to be vigilant of such abuses. In this regard Channel 7 must be commended for its program The Report, which strongly impacted on the establishment of this inquiry and which examined the Reynolds/Harris case. Ultimately, the government of the day is responsible for justice administration and its accountability will be judged in the ballot boxes. Perhaps the new Attorney-General, Mr Foley, will address these most serious matters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to bring to your attention the case of Dr Michael Wynne. Dr Wynne, a Queensland surgeon, has been a whistleblower in regard to the conduct of National Medical Enterprises. His case illustrates the way in which the law can be misused to stop whistleblowers from speaking out and the fact that multinational companies can pursue whistleblowers from outside Australia. National Medical is one of the largest and wealthiest owners of hospitals in the United States of America. It purchased a controlling interest in the Western Australia company Markalinga in December 1991. Markalinga was renamed Australian Medical Enterprises.

PARA.TAB: National Medical has recently paid out hundreds of millions of dollars to settle actions which include fraud, bribing doctors and even, extraordinarily, kidnapping patients. Over half of National Medical's US hospitals are now listed in a guilty plea to pay bounty for patient referrals. Australian Medical contracted to pay National Medical over $1 million a year for the services of a senior National Medical administrator and for access to National Medical's business expertise.

Dr Wynne first became alerted to National Medical's practices in 1988 when he went to Singapore following the death of his son. This was long before they were exposed in the United States but his protestations then fell on deaf ears.

In 1992 and 1993 Dr Wynne personally undertook an investigation of National Medical's practices, travelling to the USA at his own expense. The documents he brought back were a factor that caused the health department in New South Wales to advise against the granting of licences. The health department stressed the `lack of frankness' displayed by Australian Medical in its dealings with the department. National Medical claimed that the US directors of the Australian company knew nothing of the fraud. They claimed this occurred in a few hospitals only.

The health department was overruled by a judge delegate. Subsequent documents obtained by Dr Wynne from the USA included monthly reports to Australian Medical's US directors. These reported on the business practices in the hospitals where the fraud was perpetrated. The company's further expansion was restricted and they have now left Australia. This is in no small measure due to Dr Wynne's efforts.

As I mentioned previously, Dr Wynne's suspicions were aroused in 1988 and over the next few years he made his own confidential inquiries. He was concerned at the adverse consequences of National Medical's practices for patient care. He took action through the Singapore Medical Council and two doctors were suspended from practice.
In August 1991, Dr Wynne wrote to the chairman of the Singapore Medical Council to advise him of his concerns about National Medical's business practices in Singapore. I quote from this letter:

SPEECH.PARA: It (the information he obtained) suggested the exploitation of patients and the presence of unscrupulous and criminal activities in some portions of the medical services provided.

Those who ran the hospitals in Singapore subsequently became directors and administrators in Australian Medical. During 1993, Dr Wynne repeatedly raised his concerns with Australian Medical's Australian directors. Instead of addressing his concerns the company's lawyers threatened him with an action for defamation.

PARA.TAB: In October 1994, Dr Wynne obtained court documents from Singapore. In these a surgeon, Dr Alan Ng, alleged in evidence that hospital administrators, including those in Australia, had offered him financial rewards based on the number of patients he admitted to this hospital. The hospital's lawyer accepted that these negotiations had taken place but accused the doctor of proposing the unethical practices.

Before that trial the hospital indicated that several of those present at the meetings with Dr Ng would give evidence. The hospital did not call any of its witnesses to challenge Dr Ng's evidence, nor did they produce any evidence to support the slur they cast on his integrity. Subsequent to this, National Medical has pleaded guilty to identical practices in the USA.

Dr Wynne now felt an obligation to act. He was guided by the directive of the World Medical Association. This was formulated by the World Medical Assembly in October 1993. Both the Australian and the American medical associations are members of the World Medical Association. This directive states:

SPEECH.PARA: Should medical practitioners perceive circumstances which might adversely affect patient health, it is their duty to inform responsible authorities so that remedial action may be taken.

Should responsible authorities decline to take remedial action, reasons for the decision should be made known to the medical practitioners who reported the circumstances. Should such notification not be provided or should the rationale for the decision prove unconvincing, the medical practitioners concerned have a duty to take further actions.

Singapore authorities had not been receptive to Dr Wynne's concerns. Dr Wynne took steps to inform doctors in Australia and Singapore of National Medical's business strategies. He attempted to warn them of the pressures to which they might be subjected and the inducements which they might be offered.

PARA.TAB: Dr Wynne also took these court documents to Mr Griffin, Australian Medical's Australian chairman. Dr Wynne asked Mr Griffin to stand these persons aside while the matter was investigated. Mr Griffin refused to do so. The persons concerned had all been promoted. Some held senior positions in National Medical's empire and in the Federation of American Health Systems. This federation is a powerful group representing corporate medicine in Washington. It is dominated by National Medical Enterprises and Colombia Healthcare. Dr Wynne sent the court documents to this federation. They have never been acknowledged.

Soon after this, Dr Wynne received threats of defamation actions from the Singapore hospital, from Australian Medical and from Denis Brown, the National Medical administrator appointed to run the hospitals in Australia. These threats demanded that Dr Wynne sign retractions and admit that the aspersions he had cast and the allegations he had made were totally without foundation. Dr Wynne refused.

Denis Brown commenced a defamation action in March 1995. Dr Wynne made three applications to the court for orders that Brown detail properly what his claim was. Seven months later when Brown withdrew his action he had still not properly formulated his claim. Company reports indicate that National Medical funded this action. Brown's expenses exceeded $63,000.

Three days after Brown withdrew his action, Dr Wynne was served with a writ from the Singapore hospitals. Dr Wynne does not believe that he has overstepped the limits of legitimate comment but he is aware that the law in Singapore does not encourage whistleblowers. He intends to contest this action. Both of these actions relate to Dr Wynne's attempts to fulfil his obligations under the World Medical Association's directives and warn his medical colleagues of National Medical's unethical business practices. Dr Wynne has not been cowed by these actions.

Under the agreement which National Medical made with the US justice department when it pleaded guilty to criminal charges in June 1994, National Medical set up an ethics committee and a compliance program. To escape its past, National Medical has changed its name to Tenet Healthcare. It claims that this new name with its positive associative meaning reflects a new commitment to integrity. I quote from National Medical's company report to the United States Securities and Exchange Commission:

SPEECH.PARA: Our compliance program is directed by a management level committee, chaired by Michael H. Focht Sr., president and chief operating officer, and supervised by the ethics and quality assurance committee of the board. We have made it very clear that NME will not tolerate ethical misconduct.

A curriculum vitae issued by National Medical in 1993 indicates that Focht was president of National Medical's international division at the time when Dr Ng alleged the company's vice-president and other staff were offering him unethical inducements. It also indicated that he was a director of the Federation of American Health Systems. He became a director of Australian Medical in 1993. He is therefore likely to have been involved in the decisions to refuse to investigate the Ng allegations and to prosecute Dr Wynne through the courts.

PARA.TAB: Dr Wynne believes that Tenet cannot claim a new integrity and a willingness to address ethical issues when at the same time it refuses to explain why it failed to challenge allegations of unethical practices and then launched defamation actions against those who challenge their failure to do so. Dr Wynne is asking National Medical to honour its public commitment to integrity and its statement that it will not tolerate ethical misconduct. He has asked Tenet's ethics committee to investigate the conduct of National Medical's international division in Singapore, to investigate their refusal to explain why they did not properly contest the Ng allegations and to examine the ethical implications involved in taking defamation actions against him.

He is particularly concerned at the possible involvement of Focht in these activities because Focht is now in overall charge of Tenet's compliance program. The welfare of patients in Tenet's hospitals will depend on the integrity which Focht displays in fulfilling his obligations under the compliance program. Dr Wynne is asking his medical colleagues in the USA to support his complaint. He believes that strong pressure will be required to induce Tenet to confront the evidence he has supplied.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak very briefly about the exposure draft of an animal welfare bill and then seek leave to table it. The bill is in response to a Senate select committee's inquiry into animal welfare in 1985. Some five years ago an initial draft was produced in response to that committee's findings. The Humane Society International redrafted it in early 1995 and asked the Greens (WA) to present it as an exposure draft for wide ranging comment.

PARA.TAB: The purpose of the bill is to recognise the now widely accepted principle that animal welfare issues are a major community concern. The exposure draft seeks to place animal welfare issues on the national agenda, provide a positive Commonwealth approach to animal welfare and set standards for the behaviour of humans in their relationships with animals. Former federal environment minister Graham Richardson, if somewhat flippant, recognised that when he said that the 1990s is the age of animal welfare. He was talking about the control of kangaroos, but nevertheless I think there is a recognition that it is of increasing importance.

The bill seeks to provide the legal framework for an effective, efficient and responsible system for the management of animal welfare, balancing economic viability with the ethical care needed to ensure that the most humane methods of treatment are used. This bill is being tabled today in order to obtain community consultation. We welcome any comments on it from all stakeholders—industry groups and community groups. Aspects of the bill have been highlighted because they involve special questions that will be dealt with during the community consultation process. I seek leave to table the bill.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 October (Hansard page 2622) Senator Margetts asked me the following question without notice:

PARA.TAB: "Is it true that the political risk cover to be provided by EFIC for the Lihir goldmine, which I understand does not have any reinsurance backing, was agreed to despite the fact that OPIC, the United States loan guarantee agency, has declined to provide similar cover on environmental grounds?"
The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

I am advised that support from the United States investment guarantee agency, the Overseas Private Investment Corporation (OPIC) for the potential supply of US equipment to the Lihir mining venture in Papua New Guinea was contemplated. In the event OPIC chose not to proceed. OPIC has not made the reasons public. Consequently I am not in a position to comment on the extent of OPIC's

ANSWER.PARA: analysis of the environmental issues, or what factors may have been relevant to the decision of an agency of another government not to proceed.

PARA.TAB: However, I can say that in conjunction with the bank finance for the Lihir project, support is being provided by the World Bank's Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency (MIGA), EFIC's Canadian counterpart, the Export Development Corporation and EFIC. Environmental considerations were addressed and found to be acceptable by all three agencies in their decision to support the project.

I remind the honourable senator that Senator Faulkner and I made a joint statement announcing EFIC's support for Australian exports to the project making it clear that the Government gave very careful consideration to all the relevant factors, including environmental issues. The extent of that process was outlined in the statement and included assessment by the Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency. The Government's assessment of the Lihir gold project was carried out in accordance with the requirements of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act.
